Title: Senate Substitute for Substitute for HOUSE BILL No.
Official Title: Senate Substitute for Substitute for HOUSE BILL No.
Number of Sections: 1
Source: versions - S Sub for Sub
Media Type: application/pdf
Strikethrough Detection: 375 sections found

================================================================================

Section 1:
Session of 2025
2007
By Committee on Ways and Means
3-17
1 AN ACT making and concerning appropriations for the fiscal years ending
2 June 30, 2025, June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027, for state agencies;
3 authorizing certain transfers, capital improvement projects and fees,
4 imposing certain restrictions and limitations and directing or
5 authorizing certain receipts, disbursements, procedures and acts
6 incidental to the foregoing; amending K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 2-223, 12-
7 1775a, 12-5256, 65-180, 74-50,107, 74-8711, 74-99b34, 75-2263, 75-
8 5748, 75-6706, 75-6707, 76-775, 76-7,107, 76-7,155, 79-2989, 79-
9 3425i, 79-34,171, 79-4804 and 82a-955 and repealing the existing
10 sections.
11
12 Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of Kansas:
13 Section 1. (a) For the fiscal years ending June 30, 2025, June 30,
14 2026, and June 30, 2027, appropriations are hereby made, restrictions and
15 limitations are hereby imposed and transfers, capital improvement
16 projects, fees, receipts, disbursements and acts incidental to the foregoing
17 are hereby directed or authorized as provided in this act.
18 (b) The agencies named in this act are hereby authorized to initiate
19 and complete the capital improvement projects specified and authorized by
20 this act or for which appropriations are made by this act, subject to the
21 restrictions and limitations imposed by this act.
22 (c) This act shall not be subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 75-
23 6702(a), and amendments thereto.
24 (d) The appropriations made by this act shall not be subject to the
25 provisions of K.S.A. 46-155, and amendments thereto.
26 Sec. 2.
27 ABSTRACTERS' BOARD OF EXAMINERS
28 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
29 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year or years specified all
30 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
31 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
32 not exceed the following:
33 Abstracters' fee fund (016-00-2700-0100)
34 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.....................................$25,723
35 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027.....................................$25,733
S Sub Sub HB 2007 2
1 Sec. 3.
2 BOARD OF ACCOUNTANCY
3 (a) On the effective date of this act, the expenditure limitation
4 established for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by the state finance
5 council by section 145(f) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of
6 Kansas on the board of accountancy fee fund (082-00-2701-0100) of the
7 board of accountancy is hereby increased from $482,769 to $506,816.
8 Sec. 4.
9 BOARD OF ACCOUNTANCY
10 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
11 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year or years specified all
12 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
13 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
14 not exceed the following:
15 Board of accountancy fee fund (028-00-2701-0100)
16 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026...................................$483,965
17 Provided, That expenditures from the board of accountancy fee fund for
18 the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for official hospitality shall not
19 exceed $1,600.
20 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027...................................$489,996
21 Provided, That expenditures from the board of accountancy fee fund for
22 the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, for official hospitality shall not
23 exceed $1,600.
24 Special litigation reserve fund (028-00-2715-2700)
25 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.....................................No limit
26 Provided, That no expenditures shall be made from the special litigation
27 reserve fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, except upon the
28 approval of the director of the budget acting after ascertaining that: (1)
29 Unforeseeable occurrence or unascertainable effects of a foreseeable
30 occurrence characterize the need for the requested expenditure, and delay
31 until the next legislative session on the requested action would be contrary
32 to clause (3) of this proviso; (2) the requested expenditure is not one that
33 was rejected in the next preceding session of the legislature and is not
34 contrary to known legislative policy; and (3) the requested action will
35 assist the above agency in attaining an objective or goal that bears a valid
36 relationship to powers and functions of the above agency.
37 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027.....................................No limit
38 Provided, That no expenditures shall be made from the special litigation
39 reserve fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, except upon the
40 approval of the director of the budget acting after ascertaining that: (1)
41 Unforeseeable occurrence or unascertainable effects of a foreseeable
42 occurrence characterize the need for the requested expenditure, and delay
43 until the next legislative session on the requested action would be contrary
S Sub Sub HB 2007 3
1 to clause (3) of this proviso; (2) the requested expenditure is not one that
2 was rejected in the next preceding session of the legislature and is not
3 contrary to known legislative policy; and (3) the requested action will
4 assist the above agency in attaining an objective or goal that bears a valid
5 relationship to powers and functions of the above agency.
6 (b) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the executive
7 director of the board of accountancy, with the approval of the director of
8 the budget, may transfer moneys from the board of accountancy fee fund
9 (028-00-2701-0100) to the special litigation reserve fund (028-00-2715-
10 2700) of the board of accountancy: Provided, That the aggregate of such
11 transfers for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, shall not exceed
12 $20,000: Provided further, That the executive director of the board of
13 accountancy shall certify each such transfer of moneys to the director of
14 accounts and reports and shall transmit a copy of each such certification to
15 the director of the budget and the director of legislative research.
16 (c) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, the executive director
17 of the board of accountancy, with the approval of the director of the
18 budget, may transfer moneys from the board of accountancy fee fund
19 (028-00-2701-0100) to the special litigation reserve fund (028-00-2715-
20 2700) of the board of accountancy: Provided, That the aggregate of such
21 transfers for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, shall not exceed
22 $20,000: Provided further, That the executive director of the board of
23 accountancy shall certify each such transfer of moneys to the director of
24 accounts and reports and shall transmit a copy of each such certification to
25 the director of the budget and the director of legislative research.
26 Sec. 5.
27 STATE BANK COMMISSIONER
28 (a) On the effective date of this act, the expenditure limitation
29 established for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section 145(f) of
30 chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas on the bank commissioner
31 fee fund (094-00-2811) of the state bank commissioner is hereby
32 decreased from $13,607,801 to $13,557,797.
33 Sec. 6.
34 STATE BANK COMMISSIONER
35 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
36 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year or years specified all
37 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
38 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
39 not exceed the following:
40 Bank commissioner fee fund (094-00-2811)
41 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026..............................$13,667,399
42 Provided, That expenditures from the bank commissioner fee fund for the
43 fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for official hospitality for the division of
S Sub Sub HB 2007 4
1 consumer and mortgage lending shall not exceed $1,000: Provided further,
2 That expenditures from the bank commissioner fee fund for the fiscal year
3 ending June 30, 2026, for official hospitality for the division of banking
4 shall not exceed $2,000.
5 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027..............................$13,711,453
6 Provided, That expenditures from the bank commissioner fee fund for the
7 fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, for official hospitality for the division of
8 consumer and mortgage lending shall not exceed $1,000: Provided further,
9 That expenditures from the bank commissioner fee fund for the fiscal year
10 ending June 30, 2027, for official hospitality for the division of banking
11 shall not exceed $2,000.
12 Bank examination and investigation fund (094-00-2013-1010)
13 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.....................................No limit
14 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027.....................................No limit
15 Consumer education settlement fund (094-00-2560-2500)
16 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.....................................No limit
17 Provided, That expenditures may be made from the consumer education
18 settlement fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for consumer
19 education purposes, which may be in accordance with contracts for such
20 activities, which are hereby authorized to be entered into by the state bank
21 commissioner or the deputy commissioner of the consumer and mortgage
22 lending division, as the case may require, and the entities conducting such
23 activities.
24 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027.....................................No limit
25 Provided, That expenditures may be made from the consumer education
26 settlement fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, for consumer
27 education purposes, which may be in accordance with contracts for such
28 activities, which are hereby authorized to be entered into by the state bank
29 commissioner or the deputy commissioner of the consumer and mortgage
30 lending division, as the case may require, and the entities conducting such
31 activities.
32 Litigation expense fund (094-00-2499-2499)
33 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.....................................No limit
34 Provided, That the above agency is authorized to make expenditures from
35 the litigation expense fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for
36 costs, fees and expenses associated with administrative or judicial
37 proceedings regarding the enforcement of laws administered by the
38 consumer and mortgage lending division and the enforcement and
39 collection of assessed fines, fees and consumer refunds: Provided further,
40 That, during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, a portion of the moneys
41 collected as a result of fines and investigative fees collected by the
42 consumer and mortgage lending division, as determined by the deputy of
43 the consumer and mortgage lending division, shall be deposited in the state
S Sub Sub HB 2007 5
1 treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and
2 amendments thereto, and credited to the litigation expense fund.
3 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027.....................................No limit
4 Provided, That the above agency is authorized to make expenditures from
5 the litigation expense fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, for
6 costs, fees and expenses associated with administrative or judicial
7 proceedings regarding the enforcement of laws administered by the
8 consumer and mortgage lending division and the enforcement and
9 collection of assessed fines, fees and consumer refunds: Provided further,
10 That, during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, a portion of the moneys
11 collected as a result of fines and investigative fees collected by the
12 consumer and mortgage lending division, as determined by the deputy of
13 the consumer and mortgage lending division, shall be deposited in the state
14 treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and
15 amendments thereto, and credited to the litigation expense fund.
16 (b) During the fiscal years ending June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027,
17 notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 9-2209, 9-2218, 16a-2-302 and
18 16a-6-104, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, all moneys
19 received under the Kansas mortgage business act or the uniform consumer
20 credit code for fines or settlement moneys designated for consumer
21 education shall be deposited in the state treasury in accordance with the
22 provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall be
23 credited to the consumer education settlement fund (094-00-2560-2500).
24 Sec. 7.
25 KANSAS BOARD OF BARBERING
26 (a) On the effective date of this act, the expenditure limitation
27 established for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section 145(f) of
28 chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas on the board of barbering
29 fee fund (100-00-2704-0100) of the Kansas board of barbering is hereby
30 increased from $221,901 to $324,633.
31 Sec. 8.
32 KANSAS BOARD OF BARBERING
33 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
34 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year or years specified all
35 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
36 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
37 not exceed the following:
38 Board of barbering fee fund (100-00-2704-0100)
39 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026...................................$258,595
40 Provided, That expenditures from the board of barbering fee fund for the
41 fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for official hospitality shall not exceed
42 $500: Provided, however, That in addition to any expenditure limitation
43 imposed on the board of barbering fee fund for fiscal year 2026,
S Sub Sub HB 2007 6
1 expenditures in an amount of not to exceed 90% of the balance of the
2 barbering board fee fund may be made by the above agency from such
3 fund for the fiscal year 2026 for purposes as determined necessary by the
4 above agency.
5 For the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027...................................$262,654
6 Provided, That expenditures from the board of barbering fee fund for the
7 fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, for official hospitality shall not exceed
8 $500: Provided, however, That in addition to any expenditure limitation
9 imposed on the board of barbering fee fund for fiscal year 2027,
10 expenditures in an amount of not to exceed 90% of the balance of the
11 barbering board fee fund may be made by the above agency from such
12 fund for the fiscal year 2027 for purposes as determined necessary by the
13 above agency.
14 (b) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 65-1817, and
15 amendments thereto, or any other statute, during the fiscal years ending
16 June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027, in addition to the other purposes for
17 which expenditures may be made by the above agency from moneys
18 appropriated from any special revenue fund or funds for the above agency
19 for fiscal years 2026 and 2027 as authorized by this or any other
20 appropriation act of the 2025 or 2026 regular session of the legislature,
21 expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such moneys for
22 fiscal years 2026 and 2027 to charge and collect a fee for the examination
23 of an applicant to practice barbering in an amount of not more than $150.
24 (c) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, in addition to the
25 other purposes for which expenditures may be made from the board of
26 barbering fee fund for fiscal year 2027 by the above agency, as authorized
27 by this or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the
28 legislature, expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such
29 fund to provide a plan detailing the above agency's five-year plan for the
30 above agency's vehicle use and maintenance to accomplish the statutory
31 duties of the agency to the division of the budget, house of representatives
32 committees on general government budget and appropriations and the
33 senate committee on ways and means on or before June 30, 2027.
34 Sec. 9.
35 BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES REGULATORY BOARD
36 (a) On the effective date of this act, the expenditure limitation
37 established for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section 145(f) of
38 chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas on the behavioral sciences
39 regulatory board fee fund (102-00-2730-0100) of the behavioral sciences
40 regulatory board is hereby decreased from $1,243,446 to $1,206,956.

15 Provided, That no expenditures shall be made from the special litigation
16 reserve fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, except upon the
17 approval of the director of the budget acting after ascertaining that: (1)
18 Unforeseeable occurrence or unascertainable effects of a foreseeable
19 occurrence characterize the need for the requested expenditure, and delay
20 until the next legislative session on the requested action would be contrary
21 to clause (3) of this proviso; (2) the requested expenditure is not one that
22 was rejected in the next preceding session of the legislature and is not
23 contrary to known legislative policy; and (3) the requested action will
24 assist the above agency in attaining an objective or goal that bears a valid
25 relationship to powers and functions of the above agency.

34 was rejected in the next preceding session of the legislature and is not

29 Sec. 31.
30 LEGISLATURE
31 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the state general
32 fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, the following:
33 Efficiency analysis review account..............................................$1,000,000
34 Provided, That expenditures shall be made by the above agency from the
35 efficiency analysis review account for the fiscal year ending June 30,
36 2025, to enter into one or more contracts with a professional consulting
37 service or services to assist in the review and evaluation of how data
38 analytics, statistical analysis and artificial intelligence could be used to
39 evaluate and identify potential efficiencies in state finances and state
40 agencies: Provided further, That the review and evaluation of state
41 finances shall include access to micro level data that shows revenue and
42 expenditures for the analysis of how data analytics, statistical analysis and
43 artificial intelligence would assist the legislature to identify potential
S Sub Sub HB 2007 22
1 efficiencies: And provided further, That the state agency review and
2 evaluation shall include examining the designated state agency's core
3 functions, procedures and efficiencies and analyze how data analytics,
4 statistical analysis and artificial intelligence would assist such agencies in
5 providing services more efficiently that may result in an overall reduction
6 in expenditures: And provided further, That the legislative coordinating
7 council shall have the authority to develop a scope statement, select the
8 state agencies to be reviewed and evaluated, draft a request for proposal
9 and solicit bids in an amount not to exceed $1,000,000 for such review and
10 evaluation: And provided further, That the legislative coordinating council
11 shall approve any such contract or contracts: And provided further, That
12 such professional consulting service or services shall provide a report to
13 the house committee on appropriations and the senate committee on ways
14 and means on or before January 1, 2026.
15 (b) On the effective date of this act, of the $16,978,235 appropriated
16 for the above agency for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section
17 26(a) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas from the state
18 general fund in the operations (including official hospitality) account (428-
19 00-1000-0103), the sum of $3,924,863 is hereby lapsed.

1 shall receive the same travel expenses and subsistence expenses for

14 116, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no expenditures shall
15 be made from this account for the printing and distribution of copies of the
16 permanent journals of the senate or the house of representatives to each
17 member of the legislature during fiscal year 2026: And provided further,
18 That, notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 77-138, and amendments
19 thereto, or any other statute, no expenditures shall be made from this
20 account for the printing and distribution of complete sets of the Kansas
21 Statutes Annotated to each member of the legislature in excess of one
22 complete set of the Kansas Statutes Annotated to each member at the
23 commencement of the member's first term as legislator during fiscal year
24 2026: And provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A.
25 77-138, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no expenditures
26 shall be made from this account for the legislator's name to be printed on
27 one complete set of the Kansas Statutes Annotated during fiscal year 2026:
28 And provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 77-
29 165, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no expenditures shall
30 be made from this account for the printing and delivering of a set of the
31 cumulative supplements of the Kansas Statutes Annotated to each member
32 of the legislature in excess of one cumulative supplement set of the Kansas
33 Statutes Annotated to each member of the legislature during fiscal year
34 2026: And provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A.
35 75-1005, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, expenditures may
36 be made from this account to reimburse members of the legislature for
37 expenses incurred in printing correspondence with constituents: And
38 provided further, That no expenses shall be reimbursed unless a legislator
39 has first obtained approval for such printing by the director of legislative
40 administrative services: And provided further, That such reimbursements
41 shall only be issued after a legislator provides written receipts showing
42 such expense to the director of legislative administrative services: And
43 provided further, That the maximum amount reimbursed to any legislator
S Sub Sub HB 2007 24
1 shall be equal to or less than the maximum amount allotted to any
2 legislator for constituent correspondence pursuant to policies adopted by
3 the legislative coordinating council: And provided further, That in addition
4 to the provisions of the Kansas legislative intern program pursuant to
5 legislative coordinating council policy 37, expenditures shall be made by
6 the above agency from this account in fiscal year 2026 to pay for the
7 actual mileage of Kansas legislative interns traveling to the capitol for the
8 required minimum of 12 days of attendance at the capitol.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 25
1 policies and any restrictions or limitations prescribed by the legislative
2 coordinating council: And provided further, That amounts are hereby
3 authorized to be collected for such services, facilities and supplies in
4 accordance with policies of the council: And provided further, That such
5 amounts shall be fixed in order to recover all or part of the expenses

7 consistent with policies and fees established in accordance with K.S.A. 46-
8 1207a, and amendments thereto: And provided further, That all such
9 amounts received shall be deposited in the state treasury in accordance
10 with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall
11 be credited to the legislative special revenue fund: And provided further,
12 That all donations, gifts or bequests of money for the legislative branch of
13 government that are received and accepted by the legislative coordinating
14 council shall be deposited in the state treasury and credited to an account
15 of the legislative special revenue fund: And provided further, That no
16 expenditures shall be made from this fund for any meeting of any joint
17 committee, or of any subcommittee of any joint committee, during fiscal
18 year 2026 unless such meeting is approved by the legislative coordinating
19 council: And provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of
20 K.S.A. 45-116, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no
21 expenditures shall be made from this fund for the printing and distribution

23 representatives to each member of the legislature during fiscal year 2026:

30 year 2026: And provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of
31 K.S.A. 77-138, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no
32 expenditures shall be made from this fund for the legislator's name to be
33 printed on one complete set of the Kansas Statutes Annotated during fiscal

35 K.S.A. 77-165, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, no

18 general fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year

22 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 to install and make available

25 senate chambers during such chambers' session with access to such audio
26 limited to approved legislator devices or otherwise allow for bluetooth
27 connection and provide an independent internet network for such
28 technology and access to such network be limited to legislators.

30 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
31 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or from any special
32 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026, as authorized by this or other
33 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature,

35 fiscal year 2026 to create an interim study committee to examine the
36 KanCare 3.0 program, including, but not limited to, the requirements,
37 actions and rules of the department of health and environment and the
38 Kansas department for aging and disability services in executing the
39 program, and any actuarial and financial concerns and practices associated
40 with the KanCare 3.0 program.

7 Sec. 42.
8 STATE TREASURER
9 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the state general
10 fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the following:
11 Pregnancy compassion awareness program.................................$6,000,000
12 Provided, That expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such
13 account during fiscal year 2026 to continue the statewide program,
14 previously known as the alternatives to abortion program, to enhance and
15 increase resources that promote childbirth instead of abortion to women
16 facing unplanned pregnancies and to offer a full range of services,
17 including pregnancy support centers, adoption assistance and maternity
18 homes: Provided further, That the program shall include only the
19 following services: Counseling and mentoring; care coordination for
20 prenatal services, including connecting clients to health programs;
21 providing educational materials and information about pregnancy and
22 parenting; referrals to county and social service programs, including child
23 care, transportation, housing and state and federal benefit programs;
24 classes on life skills, budgeting, parenting, stress management, job
25 training, job placement and obtaining a GED certificate; providing
26 material items, including, but not limited to, car seats, cribs, maternity
27 clothes, infant diapers and formula; and support groups in maternity
28 homes: And provided further, That program services shall be made
29 available to any Kansas resident who is a pregnant woman, the biological
30 father of an unborn child, the biological or adoptive parent or legal
31 guardian of a child 24 months of age or younger, a program participant
32 who has experienced the loss of a child or a parent or legal guardian of a
33 pregnant child who is a program participant: And provided further, That the
34 provision and delivery of services under the program shall be dependent
35 on participant needs as assessed by the nonprofit organization providing
36 the services and not otherwise prioritized by any state agency: And
37 provided further, That program services shall be available to participants
38 only during pregnancy and continuing for up to 24 months after birth of
39 the child: And provided further, That the state treasurer shall continue to
40 contract with the nonprofit organization that was awarded such contract in
41 fiscal year 2025 to provide services under the pregnancy compassion
42 awareness program, and such nonprofit organization shall subcontract with
43 existing pregnancy centers, adoption agencies, maternity homes and social
S Sub Sub HB 2007 40
1 service organizations to provide program services to promote childbirth
2 instead of abortion: And provided further, That such contract extension
3 shall be for a term not longer than one year: And provided further, That the
4 selected contractor and any subcontractors may provide services in
5 addition to the enumerated program services, but such services shall not be
6 funded through the pregnancy compassion awareness program: And
7 provided further, That the state treasurer shall include as a condition of the
8 contract extension with the nonprofit organization selected to provide
9 program services: (1) The assessment of an administrative fine for failure
10 to satisfy program requirements, including required reporting, or for the
11 intentional or reckless misuse of any funds awarded by the terms of such
12 contract, and such fine shall be in the amount of 10% of the funds awarded
13 by the terms of such contract and shall be deposited into the state treasury
14 in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and amendments
15 thereto, to the credit of the state general fund; and (2) that such nonprofit
16 organization shall submit a report to the legislature and the state treasurer
17 on or before June 30, 2026, on the administration of the program during
18 fiscal year 2026, including: The number of clients; the number of clients
19 who participated in case management services; the number of case
20 management hours provided to clients; the number of clients engaged in
21 educational services or job training and placement activities; the number
22 of newborns who were born to program participants; the number of such
23 newborns placed for adoption; the number of fathers who participated in
24 program services; the number of client satisfaction surveys completed; and
25 any other information that shows the success of the contractor's
26 administration of the program: And provided further, That the state
27 treasurer shall establish the pregnancy compassion public awareness
28 program to be administered by the same nonprofit organization contracted
29 with to provide pregnancy compassion awareness program services: And
30 provided further, That the purpose of the public awareness program is to
31 help pregnant women who are at risk of having abortions to be made
32 aware of the pregnancy compassion awareness program services: And
33 provided further, That the public awareness program shall include the
34 development and promotion of a website that provides a geographically
35 indexed list of available pregnancy compassion awareness program
36 services and nonprofit subcontractors that provide services: And provided
37 further, That the public awareness program may include, but shall not be
38 limited to, the use of television, radio, outdoor advertising, newspapers,
39 magazines, other print media and the internet to provide information about
40 the pregnancy compassion awareness program services and
41 subcontractors: And provided further, That, to the greatest extent possible,
42 the secretary for children and families shall supplement and match moneys
43 appropriated for the pregnancy compassion awareness program with
S Sub Sub HB 2007 41
1 federal and other public and private moneys, and such moneys shall be
2 prioritized to be used preferentially for the program and the public
3 awareness program and be transferred from the special revenue fund or
4 funds of the Kansas department for children and families as identified by
5 the secretary for children and families to the pregnancy compassion
6 awareness program account to be expended for such programs: Provided,
7 however, That the pregnancy compassion awareness program and the
8 pregnancy compassion public awareness program and any moneys
9 appropriated or expended therefor shall not be used to perform, induce,
10 assist in the performing or inducing of or refer for abortions, and moneys
11 appropriated or expended for such programs shall not be granted to
12 organizations or affiliates of organizations that perform, induce, assist in
13 the performing or inducing of or refer for abortions.

13 American rescue plan state relief fund.............................................No limit
14 Provided, That expenditures in an amount of not less than $3,000,000 shall
15 be made by the above agency from such fund during fiscal year 2026 to
16 administer a program for the purpose of awarding grants to eligible entities
17 to develop and administer a talent recruitment program that incentivizes
18 the relocation of households to Kansas: Provided further, That an eligible
19 entity shall be a city, county, native American tribe or nonprofit that has a
20 mission that includes economic development, workforce and talent
21 development or community development: And provided further, That an
22 eligible entity may submit a grant application to the above agency that
23 includes: (1) A talent recruitment program plan that includes: (A) Total
24 estimated cost of the program; (B) estimated individual costs for design,
25 administration, marketing and relocation incentive initiatives; (C) the
26 program's goal number of participating households; (D) estimated costs
27 incurred against the recipient for each participating household; (E)
28 estimated state and local tax revenue attributable to participating
29 households; and (F) estimated total economic impact attributable to
30 participating households; and (2) proof that the applicant has local
31 investments and in-kind donations of at least 20% of the total program
32 cost: And provided further, That the above agency shall award a grant in an
33 amount of not to exceed $250,000 for each approved grant application:
34 And provided further, That the above agency shall expend 50% of the
35 amount of the grant to each approved applicant for receipt of grant funds
36 subject to this proviso at the time of approval: And provided further, That
37 the above agency shall expend grant funds from the remaining 50% of the
38 amount of the grant to each approved applicant when such applicant's
39 program has achieved half of the talent recruitment program plan's goal of
40 number of participating households as submitted in the applicable grant
41 application: Provided, however, That if the program has not achieved such
42 half of the goal of number of participating households, the above agency
43 shall not expend the remaining grant funds: And provided further, That the
S Sub Sub HB 2007 45
1 grant recipient shall develop and administer a talent recruitment program
2 that provides incentives for a participating household to relocate or
3 commit to relocate to Kansas: And provided further, That a grant recipient
4 may contract with a third-party entity to develop and administer such
5 talent recruitment program: And provided further, That to be approved to
6 participate in a talent recruitment program, a household shall have an
7 annual income of at least $55,000 and such household has submitted an
8 application to participate in the talent recruitment program and has been
9 approved by the program to participate in the program: And provided
10 further, That a grant recipient shall provide the above agency quarterly
11 reports on the recipient's talent recruitment program for each grant
12 awarded including: (i) Total number of household applications received by
13 the recipient; (ii) total number of households approved by the recipient for
14 participation in the program; (iii) costs incurred against the recipient for
15 each approved household; (iv) annual income and occupation of each
16 approved household; and (v) the economic impact of the program, such as
17 state and local tax revenue contributed and new consumer spending
18 attributable to a participating household: And provided further, That,
19 notwithstanding the provisions of any other statute to the contrary,
20 incentives received by a participating household shall not be construed to
21 preclude the participating household or an individual of a participating
22 household from participating in programs or receiving other available
23 statewide incentives: And provided further, That, as used in this proviso,
24 "participating household" means a household that either has successfully
25 relocated to Kansas or has committed to relocating to Kansas.
26 STAR bonds food sales tax
27 revenue replacement fund............................................................No limit
28 Provided, That on July 1, 2025, the secretary of revenue, in consultation
29 with the governing body of each city with a population of 30,000 or less,
30 as certified to the secretary of state by the division of the budget in
31 accordance with K.S.A. 11-201, and amendments thereto, that has
32 established a STAR bond project district prior to December 31, 2022, shall

39 6.5%: Provided further, That on or before September 1, 2025, the director
40 of accounts and reports shall certify to the state treasurer the amounts so

42 the STAR bonds food sales tax revenue replacement fund the aggregate of
43 all amounts so certified: And provided further, That on or before October
S Sub Sub HB 2007 46
1 15, 2025, the state treasurer shall pay from the STAR bonds food sales tax
2 revenue replacement fund to the appropriate city bond finance, debt

4 reports for each city: And provided further, That at the same time the
5 secretary of revenue transmits certification to the director of accounts and

8 (c) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 75-648, and
9 amendments thereto, or any other statute, on July 1, 2025, or as soon

11 shall transfer $50,000 from the Kansas postsecondary education savings
12 expense fund (670-00-2096-2000) of the state treasurer to the KS ABLE

26 the state corporation commission: And provided further, That the state
27 corporation commission is hereby authorized to enter into contracts with
28 other state agencies and with persons, as may be necessary, to administer
29 the energy efficiency revolving loan program: And provided further, That
30 any person who agrees to receive money from the energy efficiency
31 revolving loan program – ARRA federal fund shall enter into an agreement
32 requiring such person to submit a written report to the state corporation
33 commission detailing and accounting for all expenditures and receipts
34 related to the use of the moneys received from the energy efficiency
35 revolving loan program – ARRA federal fund: And provided further, That
36 moneys repaid to the energy efficiency revolving loan program shall be
37 deposited in the state treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A.
38 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall be credited to the energy
39 efficiency revolving loan program – ARRA federal fund: And provided
40 further, That, on or before the 10th day of each month, the director of
41 accounts and reports shall transfer from the state general fund to the
42 energy efficiency revolving loan program – ARRA federal fund interest
43 earnings based on: (1) The average daily balance of repaid moneys in the
S Sub Sub HB 2007 59
1 energy efficiency revolving loan program – ARRA federal fund for the
2 preceding month; and (2) the net earnings rate for the pooled money
3 investment portfolio for the preceding month.

15 Municipal natural gas utility distribution
16 grant program ARPA fund (143-00-3756)...................................No limit
17 Provided, That expenditures shall be made from the municipal natural gas
18 utility distribution grant program ARPA fund for providing small
19 municipalities currently being served by a natural gas gathering field to
20 design, construct and install natural gas distribution lines that connect to a
21 natural gas service provider and infrastructure for such lines: Provided
22 further, That the above agency shall establish an application process to
23 award such grants to eligible municipalities: And provided further, That the
24 above agency shall expend a partial amount of the grant to eligible
25 municipalities for the completion of a natural gas cost of service and
26 revenue rate requirement study on proposed natural gas distribution lines:
27 And provided further, That the municipality shall contract with an external
28 and reputable entity to conduct and complete a natural gas cost of service
29 and revenue rate requirement study that studies the cost of service of such
30 distribution lines, including the cost of the natural gas, natural gas
31 transport, distribution, distribution labor, maintenance and administration
32 of such lines, and the costs of maintaining and upgrading the natural gas
33 distribution lines in the city limits of such municipality: And provided
34 further, That such study shall provide the municipality with a natural gas
35 utility rate that recovers actual costs for the maintenance and necessary
36 upgrades of the natural gas distribution lines in the city limits of such
37 municipality: And provided further, That such municipality shall
38 implement and charge a rate that recovers the actual costs for the
39 maintenance and necessary upgrades of the natural gas distribution lines in
40 the city limits of such municipality: And provided further, That such
41 municipality shall identify and contract with a natural gas service provider
42 for the provision of such natural gas utility: And provided further, That,
43 upon completion of such study, implementation of such rate and contract
S Sub Sub HB 2007 60
1 provision of service, the above agency shall expend the remaining amount
2 of the grant to the municipality for the design, construction and installation
3 of such lines and infrastructure.

22 expenditure limitation prescribed by subsection (a) are not expended or

10 director of the budget that shall be equal to 75% of the amount estimated
11 by the director of the budget to be transferred and credited to the state
12 economic development initiatives fund during the fiscal year ending June
13 30, 2026, except that such amount shall be proportionally adjusted during
14 fiscal year 2026 with respect to any change in the moneys to be transferred

16 fiscal year 2026. All moneys transferred and credited to the state economic
17 development initiatives fund during fiscal year 2026 shall reduce the
18 amount debited and credited to the state economic development initiatives
19 fund under this subsection.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 73
1 circumstances and unanticipated reductions in expenditures or

4 (3) As used in this subsection, "regents agency" means the state board
5 of regents, Fort Hays state university, Kansas state university, Kansas state
6 university extension systems and agriculture research programs, Kansas
7 state university veterinary medical center, Emporia state university,
8 Pittsburg state university, the university of Kansas, the university of
9 Kansas medical center and Wichita state university.
10 (4) The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to:
11 (A) Any money held in trust in a trust fund or held in trust in any
12 other special revenue fund or funds of any regents agency;
13 (B) any moneys received from any agency or authority of the federal
14 government or from any other federal source, other than any such federal
15 moneys that are credited to or may be received and credited to special
16 revenue funds of a regents agency and that are determined by the state
17 board of regents to be federal moneys that may be transferred to and
18 debited to the 27th payroll adjustment account of the state general fund by
19 the director of accounts and reports pursuant to this subsection;
20 (C) any account of the Kansas educational building fund; or
21 (D) any fund of any regents agency in the state treasury, as
22 determined by the director of the budget, that would experience financial
23 or administrative difficulties as a result of executing the provisions of this
24 subsection, including, but not limited to, cash flow problems, the inability
25 to meet ordinary expenditure obligations, or any conflicts with prevailing
26 contracts, compacts or other provisions of law.
27 (5) Each amount transferred from any special revenue fund of any
28 regents agency to the state general fund pursuant to this subsection is
29 transferred to reimburse the state general fund for accounting, auditing,
30 budgeting, legal, payroll, personnel and purchasing services and any other
31 governmental services that are performed on behalf of the regents agency
32 involved by other state agencies that receive appropriations from the state
33 general fund to provide such services.

23 subsection shall be the maximum amount possible while maintaining an
24 adequate cash balance necessary to make expenditures for prize payments
25 and operating costs: And provided further, That the transfers prescribed in
26 this subsection shall include the total profit attributed to the special
27 veterans benefit game under K.S.A. 74-8724, and amendments thereto:
28 And provided further, That the transfers prescribed by this subsection shall
29 be made in lieu of transfers under K.S.A. 74-8711(d), and amendments
30 thereto, for fiscal year 2026.

19 from the tribal gaming fund for fiscal year 2026 for the state gaming
20 agency regulatory oversight of class III gaming, including, but not limited
21 to, the regulatory oversight and law enforcement activities of monitoring
22 compliance with tribal-state gaming compacts and conducting

26 investigations of applicants and vendors and investigations of other
27 criminal activities related to tribal gaming.

32 commission to the greyhound tourism fund of the department of commerce
33 that is directed to be made on or before June 30, 2026, by K.S.A. 74-
34 8831(b)(1), and amendments thereto, and shall transfer on or before June
35 30, 2026, the amount equal to 15% of all moneys credited to the Kansas
36 greyhound breeding development fund during the fiscal year ending June
37 30, 2026, from the Kansas greyhound breeding development fund to the
38 greyhound promotion and development fund (553-00-2561-3100) of the
39 Kansas racing and gaming commission.
40 (g) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding the
41 provisions of any other statute, the Kansas racing and gaming commission
42 is hereby authorized to fix, charge and collect additional fees to recover all
43 or part of the direct and indirect costs or operating expenses incurred or
S Sub Sub HB 2007 92
1 expected to be incurred by the Kansas racing and gaming commission for
2 the regulation of racing activities that are not otherwise recovered from a
3 parimutuel facility licensee under authority of any other statute: Provided,
4 That such fees shall be in addition to all taxes and other fees otherwise
5 authorized by law: Provided further, That such costs or operating expenses
6 shall include all or part of any auditing, drug testing, accounting, security
7 and law enforcement, licensing of any office or other facility for use by a
8 parimutuel facility licensee or projects to update and upgrade information
9 technology software or facilities of the commission and shall specifically
10 include any general operating expenses that are associated with regulatory
11 activities attributable to the entity upon which any such fee is imposed and
12 all expenses related to reopening any race track or other racing facility:
13 And provided further, That all moneys received for such fees shall be
14 deposited in the state treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A.
15 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall be credited to the state racing
16 fund (553-00-5131-5000).

33 Sec. 70.
34 DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE
35 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the state general
36 fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the following:
37 Advantage Kansas (300-00-1000)...................................................$138,992
38 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in excess of $100 as of June 30,
39 2025, in the advantage Kansas account is hereby reappropriated for fiscal
40 year 2026.
41 Purple UAS certification innovation grant account.....................$1,000,000
42 Provided, That expenditures in an amount of not less than $500,000 shall
43 be made by the above agency from such account during fiscal year 2026 to
S Sub Sub HB 2007 93
1 provide a grant to the national institute for aviation research at Wichita
2 state university to research and create an accurate and comprehensive
3 checklist necessary for blue unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) compliance,
4 which shall include the United States department of defense requirements
5 for maintenance of supply chain security necessary for manufacturers of
6 such department of defense drone technology: Provided further, That,
7 national institute for aviation research shall include specific
8 recommendations to Kansas state university Salina for the creation of a
9 purple UAS public safety and commercial credentialing process: And
10 provided further, That expenditures in an amount of not less than $500,000
11 shall be made by the above agency from such account during fiscal year
12 2026 to provide a grant to Kansas state university Salina to create a purple
13 UAS public safety and commercial credentialing process for credentialing
14 drones for commercial and public safety use: Provided, however, That if
15 such expenditures are not expended by January 1, 2026, on such date, any
16 remaining moneys in such account are hereby lapsed: And provided
17 further, That the above agency shall prepare and submit a report to the
18 legislature on the purple UAS public safety and commercial credentialing
19 process by January 20, 2026.
20 Statewide marketing campaign for high demand
21 and high wage career fields.....................................................$2,000,000
22 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in excess of $100 as of June 30,
23 2025, in the statewide marketing campaign for high demand and high
24 wage career fields account is hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026:
25 Provided further, That expenditures shall be made by the above agency
26 from the statewide marketing campaign for high demand and high wage
27 career fields account for a contract with Level Up Kansas, a Kansas
28 nonprofit, for the purpose of providing a statewide marketing campaign to
29 underskilled adult learners about training opportunities available at Kansas
30 postsecondary educational institutions in high demand and high wage
31 career fields.
32 Maintenance, repair and overhaul of airplanes..........................$15,500,000
33 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in excess of $100 as of June 30,
34 2025, in the maintenance, repair and overhaul of airplanes account is
35 hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided further, That
36 expenditures in an amount of not less than $15,500,000 shall be made by
37 the above agency from such account during fiscal year 2026 to provide for
38 the maintenance, repair and overhaul of airplanes at the airport in Topeka,
39 Kansas: And provided further, That such expenditures shall not require a
40 match of local nonstate or private moneys: And provided further, That the
41 secretary of commerce is hereby authorized to enter into a loan agreement
42 with the metropolitan Topeka airport authority for the purposes of the
43 maintenance, repair and overhaul of airplanes at the Topeka regional
S Sub Sub HB 2007 94
1 airport: And provided further, That the loan shall be at a fixed interest rate
2 and in accordance with repayment provisions and other terms and
3 conditions as may be prescribed by the secretary: And provided further,
4 That all moneys received by the secretary for repayment of loans made
5 under the maintenance, repair and overhaul of airplanes account shall be
6 deposited in the state treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A.
7 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall be credited to the state
8 general fund.
9 Any unencumbered balance in the following accounts in excess of $100 as
10 of June 30, 2025, is hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Kansas
11 semiquincentennial commission support account; housing and workforce
12 development account; home-based child care providers pilot program
13 account; sports hall of fame support account; and industrial park project
14 account.

12 (d) The secretary of commerce is hereby authorized to fix, charge and
13 collect fees during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for: (1) The
14 provision and administration of conferences held for the purposes of
15 programs and activities of the department of commerce and for which fees
16 are not specifically prescribed by statute; (2) sale of publications of the
17 department of commerce and for sale of educational and other promotional
18 items and for which fees are not specifically prescribed by statute; and (3)
19 promotional and other advertising and related economic development
20 activities and services provided under economic development programs
21 and activities of the department of commerce: Provided, That such fees
22 shall be fixed in order to recover all or part of the operating expenses
23 incurred in providing such services, conferences, publications and items,
24 advertising and other economic development activities and services
25 provided under economic development programs and activities of the
26 department of commerce for which fees are not specifically prescribed by
27 statute: Provided further, That all such fees shall be deposited in the state
28 treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and
29 amendments thereto, and shall be credited to one or more special revenue
30 fund or funds of the department of commerce as specified by the secretary
31 of commerce: And provided further, That expenditures may be made from
32 such special revenue fund or funds of the department of commerce for
33 fiscal year 2026, in accordance with the provisions of this or other
34 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature, for
35 operating expenses incurred in providing such services, conferences,
36 publications and items, advertising, programs and activities and for
37 operating expenses incurred in providing similar economic development
38 activities and services provided under economic development programs
39 and activities of the department of commerce.
40 (e) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
41 made by the department of commerce from moneys appropriated in any
42 special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 for the department of
43 commerce as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025
S Sub Sub HB 2007 100
1 regular session of the legislature, notwithstanding the provisions of any
2 other statute, expenditures may be made by the department of commerce
3 from moneys appropriated in any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal
4 year 2026 for official hospitality.
5 (f) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the secretary of
6 commerce, with the approval of the director of the budget, may transfer
7 any part of any item of appropriation for the fiscal year ending June 30,
8 2026, from the state economic development initiatives fund for the
9 department of commerce to another item of appropriation for fiscal year
10 2026 from the state economic development initiatives fund for the
11 department of commerce. The secretary of commerce shall certify each
12 such transfer to the director of accounts and reports and shall transmit a
13 copy of each such certification to the director of legislative research.
14 (g) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding the
15 provisions of K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, or any other
16 statute to the contrary, in addition to the other purposes for which
17 expenditures may be made by the above agency from moneys appropriated
18 from the state general fund or any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal
19 year 2026 as authorized by this or any other appropriation act of the 2025
20 regular session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made from such
21 moneys for the secretary of commerce to approve a city or county to
22 finance a rural redevelopment project, as defined in K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
23 amendments thereto, without the issuance of special obligation bonds up to
24 an amount of not to exceed $25,000,000 for each such project: Provided,
25 That such rural redevelopment project costs shall be made payable, both as
26 to principal and interest, from any source as provided in K.S.A. 12-
27 17,169(a)(1)(A) through (I), and amendments thereto.
28 (h) (1) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding
29 the provisions of the STAR bonds financing act, K.S.A. 12-17,160 through
30 12-17,180, and amendments thereto, or any other statute to the contrary, in
31 addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the
32 above agency from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or
33 any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 as authorized by this
34 or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the
35 legislature, expenditures may be made from such moneys for the secretary
36 of commerce to approve a STAR bond project for a major amusement park
37 or historic theater: Provided, That such approval shall be upon adoption of
38 a STAR bond project plan and establishment of a STAR bond project
39 district by a city or county for such major amusement park project or
40 historic theater in accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,164 through 12-17,166,
41 and amendments thereto: Provided further, That such major amusement
42 park project or historic theater shall be eligible for financing by special
43 obligation bonds payable from revenues described by K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)
S Sub Sub HB 2007 101
1 (1), and amendments thereto: And provided further, That such city or
2 county is authorized to issue such special obligation bonds in one or more
3 series to finance the undertaking of such major amusement park project or
4 historic theater in accordance with the provisions of the STAR bonds
5 financing act: And provided further, That the secretary shall review the
6 STAR bond project plan and determine whether to approve such plan in
7 accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,167, and amendments thereto: And provided
8 further, That any special obligation bonds issued to finance the major
9 amusement park project or historic theater shall be subject to the
10 provisions of the STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That
11 such major amusement park and historic theater costs shall be considered
12 project costs for the purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and amendments
13 thereto: And provided further, That a major amusement park area shall be
14 considered an eligible area for purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
15 amendments thereto: And provided further, That all such property included
16 in, added to or removed from the STAR bond project district established
17 pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of the STAR
18 bonds financing act: And provided further, That if such major amusement
19 park project or historic theater uses state sales tax financing pursuant to
20 K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, such project shall be subject
21 to the requirements of K.S.A. 12-17,176, and amendments thereto: And
22 provided further, That in the event that the city or county shall default in
23 the payment of any STAR bonds payable from revenues described in
24 K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)(1), and amendments thereto, no public funds shall be
25 used to pay the holders thereof except as specifically authorized by the
26 STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That copies of all
27 retailers' sales, use and transient guest tax returns filed with the secretary
28 of revenue in connection with such major amusement park project shall be
29 subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-17,174, and amendments thereto.
30 (2) For purposes of this subsection:
31 (A) "Amusement rides" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 44-
32 1601, and amendments thereto, and includes such amusement rides and
33 further include buildings necessary to house and operate such amusement
34 park rides, buildings immediately adjacent and attached to such
35 amusement park rides and a building necessary to house a conference
36 center within the major amusement park area.
37 (B) "Major amusement park" means a project with amusement rides
38 and related attractions and upon which the secretary has made a finding
39 that capital improvements of not less than $100,000,000 will be built in the
40 state to construct the major amusement park.
41 (C) "Major amusement park area" means an area containing a major
42 amusement park.
43 (i) On July 1, 2025, or as soon thereafter as moneys are available, the
S Sub Sub HB 2007 102
1 director of accounts and reports shall transfer $4,000,000 from the
2 American rescue plan – state fiscal relief – federal fund (252-00-3756) of
3 the governor's department to the American rescue plan state relief – federal
4 fund (300-00-3756) of the department of commerce.
5 (j) On July 1, 2025, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
6 $7,000,000 from the state general fund to the attracting powerful economic
7 expansion payroll incentive fund (300-00-2943) established by K.S.A.
8 2024 Supp. 74-50,316, and amendments thereto.
9 (k) On July 1, 2025, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
10 $3,000,000 from the state general fund to the attracting powerful economic
11 expansion new employee training and education fund (300-00-2944)
12 established by K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 74-50,318, and amendments thereto.
13 (l) On July 1, 2025, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
14 $800,000 from the state general fund to the attracting powerful economic
15 expansion residency incentive fund (300-00-2945) established by K.S.A.
16 2024 Supp. 74-50,323, and amendments thereto.
17 Sec. 71.
18 DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE
19 (a) (1) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, notwithstanding
20 the provisions of the STAR bonds financing act, K.S.A. 12-17,160 through
21 12-17,180, and amendments thereto, or any other statute to the contrary, in
22 addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the
23 above agency from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or
24 any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2027 as authorized by this
25 or any other appropriation act of the 2025 or 2026 regular session of the
26 legislature, expenditures may be made from such moneys for the secretary
27 of commerce to approve a STAR bond project for a major amusement park
28 or historic theater: Provided, That such approval shall be upon adoption of
29 a STAR bond project plan and establishment of a STAR bond project
30 district by a city or county for such major amusement park project or
31 historic theater in accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,164 through 12-17,166,
32 and amendments thereto: Provided further, That such major amusement
33 park project or historic theater shall be eligible for financing by special
34 obligation bonds payable from revenues described by K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)
35 (1), and amendments thereto: And provided further, That such city or
36 county is authorized to issue such special obligation bonds in one or more
37 series to finance the undertaking of such major amusement park project or
38 historic theater in accordance with the provisions of the STAR bonds
39 financing act: And provided further, That the secretary shall review the
40 STAR bond project plan and determine whether to approve such plan in
41 accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,167, and amendments thereto: And provided
42 further, That any special obligation bonds issued to finance the major
43 amusement park project or historic theater shall be subject to the
S Sub Sub HB 2007 103
1 provisions of the STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That
2 such major amusement park and historic theater costs shall be considered
3 project costs for the purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and amendments
4 thereto: And provided further, That a major amusement park area shall be
5 considered an eligible area for purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
6 amendments thereto: And provided further, That all such property included
7 in, added to or removed from the STAR bond project district established
8 pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of the STAR
9 bonds financing act: And provided further, That if such major amusement
10 park project or historic theater uses state sales tax financing pursuant to
11 K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, such project shall be subject
12 to the requirements of K.S.A. 12-17,176, and amendments thereto: And
13 provided further, That in the event that the city or county shall default in
14 the payment of any STAR bonds payable from revenues described in
15 K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)(1), and amendments thereto, no public funds shall be
16 used to pay the holders thereof except as specifically authorized by the
17 STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That copies of all
18 retailers' sales, use and transient guest tax returns filed with the secretary
19 of revenue in connection with such major amusement park project shall be
20 subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-17,174, and amendments thereto.
21 (2) For purposes of this subsection:
22 (A) "Amusement rides" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 44-
23 1601, and amendments thereto, and includes such amusement rides and
24 further include buildings necessary to house and operate such amusement
25 park rides, buildings immediately adjacent and attached to such
26 amusement park rides and a building necessary to house a conference
27 center within the major amusement park area.
28 (B) "Major amusement park" means a project with amusement rides
29 and related attractions and upon which the secretary has made a finding
30 that capital improvements of not less than $100,000,000 will be built in the
31 state to construct the major amusement park.
32 (C) "Major amusement park area" means an area containing a major
33 amusement park.
34 (b) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2027, in addition to the
35 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
36 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special
37 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2027 as authorized by this or any
38 other appropriation act of the 2025 or 2026 regular session of the
39 legislature, expenditures shall be made from such moneys for the secretary
40 of commerce to submit a report on economic development incentives by
41 economic development incentive program that includes the total incentives
42 awarded to each program and the estimated fiscal impact on the state
43 general fund during fiscal year 2027 to the house of representatives
S Sub Sub HB 2007 104
1 committee on appropriations and the senate committee on ways and
2 means.
3 Sec. 72.
4 KANSAS HOUSING RESOURCES CORPORATION
5 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
6 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all
7 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
8 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
9 not exceed the following:
10 State housing trust fund (175-00-7370-7000)...................................No limit
11 Provided, That all expenditures from the state housing trust fund shall be
12 made by the Kansas housing resources corporation for the purposes of
13 administering and supporting housing programs of the Kansas housing
14 resources corporation as authorized by K.S.A. 74-8959, and amendments
15 thereto, and this section: Provided further, That of the moneys
16 appropriated in the state housing trust fund and identified as moneys for
17 the rural housing revolving loan program, as authorized by section 28 of
18 chapter 81 of the 2022 Session Laws of Kansas, or identified as moneys
19 for the housing revolving loan program, as authorized by section 77 of
20 chapter 82 of the 2023 Session Laws of Kansas, expenditures may be
21 made by the above agency from such identified moneys in such fund for
22 fiscal year 2026 for loans to a local unit of government, political
23 subdivision of the state, not-for-profit organizations focused on housing
24 development, for-profit or not-for-profit builder or developer for moderate
25 and low-income housing development, including infrastructure necessary
26 to support such development: And provided further, That at least 50% of
27 such expenditures shall be used in rural communities: And provided
28 further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of any statute to the contrary,
29 a local government or political subdivision of the state is hereby
30 authorized to enter into loan agreements under this program: And provided
31 further, That the provisions and restrictions of the cash basis and budget
32 laws of this state shall not apply to any loan received by a local
33 government or political subdivision under this program: And provided
34 further, That notwithstanding the provisions of any statute, the interest rate
35 for a loan to any not-for-profit organization focused on housing
36 development shall be equal to the average interest rate of certificates of
37 deposit in Kansas financial institutions in June 2025, as determined by the
38 state treasurer.

1 Aid to local units – primary

3 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in the aid to local units –

5 hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided further, That
6 prescription support expenditures shall be made from the aid to local units
7 – primary health projects account for: (1) Purchasing drug inventory under
8 section 340B of the federal public health service act for community health
9 center grantees and federally qualified health center look-alikes who
10 qualify; (2) increasing access to prescription drugs by subsidizing a
11 portion of the costs for the benefit of patients at section 340B participating
12 clinics on a sliding fee scale; and (3) expanding access to prescription
13 medication assistance programs by making expenditures to support
14 operating costs of assistance programs: And provided further, That funded
15 clinics shall be not-for-profit or publicly funded primary care clinics or
16 dental clinics, including federally qualified community health centers and
17 federally qualified community health center look-alikes, as defined by 42
18 U.S.C. § 330, that provide comprehensive primary healthcare or dental
19 services, offer sliding fee discounts based upon household income and
20 serve any person regardless of ability to pay and have a unique patient
21 panel that, at a minimum, represents the income-based disparities of the
22 community: And provided further, That policies determining patient
23 eligibility due to income or insurance status may be determined by each
24 community but must be clearly documented and posted: And provided
25 further, That of the moneys appropriated in the aid to local units – primary
26 health projects account, not less than $18,750,690 shall be distributed for
27 community-based primary care grants and services provided by the
28 community care network of Kansas.

27 recipients of state aid from the division of public health of the department
28 of health and environment and for training representatives of industries
29 affected by rules and regulations of the department of health and
30 environment relating to the division of public health: Provided further,
31 That the secretary of health and environment is hereby authorized to fix,
32 charge and collect fees in order to recover costs incurred for such
33 acquisition and distribution of literature and films and for the operation of
34 such seminars: And provided further, That such fees may be fixed in order
35 to recover all or part of such costs: And provided further, That all moneys

32 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
33 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special
34 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2025 as authorized by section 79 of

41 adults made eligible for the medical assistance program under 42 U.S.C.
42 1396a(a)(10)(A)(i)(I), 42 U.S.C. 1396u-1(b), or 42 U.S.C. 1396u-1(d):
43 Provided, That the department of health and environment shall cause
S Sub Sub HB 2007 126
1 notice of such approval by the United States centers for medicare and
2 medicaid services to be published in the Kansas register: And provided
3 further, That the changes in eligibility described in this subsection shall
4 take effect on and after January 1 or July 1 immediately following such
5 publication: And provided further, That, after such date, no additional
6 moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special revenue
7 fund shall be expended to support a 12-month continuous eligibility period
8 for the population described.

11 provided further, That the above agency shall expend moneys in such
12 account to provide coverage under the medicaid state plan for patients who
13 have a prescription for a complex power wheelchair subject to the
14 following: (1) For the service and repair of complex wheelchairs, cover the
15 complex rehabilitation supplier's time for evaluation, diagnoses and repair
16 needs by a repair technician using the current labor rate; and (2) cover an
17 annual preventative maintenance appointment and any necessary repairs
18 for such wheelchair using a preventative maintenance reimbursement code
19 established by the above agency and amount based on current market rate:
20 And provided further, That the above agency shall not require prior
21 authorization for the services, repairs and appointments established in
22 paragraphs (1) and (2): And provided further, That expenditures shall be
23 made from such moneys to submit to the centers for medicare and
24 medicaid services any required state plan amendments needed to
25 implement the provisions of this proviso section for fiscal year 2026.

6 such matching grants.
