12 (d) The secretary of commerce is hereby authorized to fix, charge and
13 collect fees during the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for: (1) The
14 provision and administration of conferences held for the purposes of
15 programs and activities of the department of commerce and for which fees
16 are not specifically prescribed by statute; (2) sale of publications of the
17 department of commerce and for sale of educational and other promotional
18 items and for which fees are not specifically prescribed by statute; and (3)
19 promotional and other advertising and related economic development
20 activities and services provided under economic development programs
21 and activities of the department of commerce: Provided, That such fees
22 shall be fixed in order to recover all or part of the operating expenses
23 incurred in providing such services, conferences, publications and items,
24 advertising and other economic development activities and services
25 provided under economic development programs and activities of the
26 department of commerce for which fees are not specifically prescribed by
27 statute: Provided further, That all such fees shall be deposited in the state
28 treasury in accordance with the provisions of K.S.A. 75-4215, and
29 amendments thereto, and shall be credited to one or more special revenue
30 fund or funds of the department of commerce as specified by the secretary
31 of commerce: And provided further, That expenditures may be made from
32 such special revenue fund or funds of the department of commerce for
33 fiscal year 2026, in accordance with the provisions of this or other
34 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature, for
35 operating expenses incurred in providing such services, conferences,
36 publications and items, advertising, programs and activities and for
37 operating expenses incurred in providing similar economic development
38 activities and services provided under economic development programs
39 and activities of the department of commerce.
40 (e) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
41 made by the department of commerce from moneys appropriated in any
42 special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 for the department of
43 commerce as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025

S Sub Sub HB 2007 100
1 regular session of the legislature, notwithstanding the provisions of any
2 other statute, expenditures may be made by the department of commerce
3 from moneys appropriated in any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal
4 year 2026 for official hospitality.
5 (f) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the secretary of
6 commerce, with the approval of the director of the budget, may transfer
7 any part of any item of appropriation for the fiscal year ending June 30,
8 2026, from the state economic development initiatives fund for the
9 department of commerce to another item of appropriation for fiscal year
10 2026 from the state economic development initiatives fund for the
11 department of commerce. The secretary of commerce shall certify each
12 such transfer to the director of accounts and reports and shall transmit a
13 copy of each such certification to the director of legislative research.
14 (g) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding the
15 provisions of K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, or any other
16 statute to the contrary, in addition to the other purposes for which
17 expenditures may be made by the above agency from moneys appropriated
18 from the state general fund or any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal
19 year 2026 as authorized by this or any other appropriation act of the 2025
20 regular session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made from such
21 moneys for the secretary of commerce to approve a city or county to
22 finance a rural redevelopment project, as defined in K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
23 amendments thereto, without the issuance of special obligation bonds up to
24 an amount of not to exceed $25,000,000 for each such project: Provided,
25 That such rural redevelopment project costs shall be made payable, both as
26 to principal and interest, from any source as provided in K.S.A. 12-
27 17,169(a)(1)(A) through (I), and amendments thereto.
28 (h) (1) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding
29 the provisions of the STAR bonds financing act, K.S.A. 12-17,160 through
30 12-17,180, and amendments thereto, or any other statute to the contrary, in
31 addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the
32 above agency from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or
33 any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 as authorized by this
34 or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the
35 legislature, expenditures may be made from such moneys for the secretary
36 of commerce to approve a STAR bond project for a major amusement park
37 or historic theater: Provided, That such approval shall be upon adoption of
38 a STAR bond project plan and establishment of a STAR bond project
39 district by a city or county for such major amusement park project or
40 historic theater in accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,164 through 12-17,166,
41 and amendments thereto: Provided further, That such major amusement
42 park project or historic theater shall be eligible for financing by special
43 obligation bonds payable from revenues described by K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)

S Sub Sub HB 2007 101
1 (1), and amendments thereto: And provided further, That such city or
2 county is authorized to issue such special obligation bonds in one or more
3 series to finance the undertaking of such major amusement park project or
4 historic theater in accordance with the provisions of the STAR bonds
5 financing act: And provided further, That the secretary shall review the
6 STAR bond project plan and determine whether to approve such plan in
7 accordance with K.S.A. 12-17,167, and amendments thereto: And provided
8 further, That any special obligation bonds issued to finance the major
9 amusement park project or historic theater shall be subject to the
10 provisions of the STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That
11 such major amusement park and historic theater costs shall be considered
12 project costs for the purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and amendments
13 thereto: And provided further, That a major amusement park area shall be
14 considered an eligible area for purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
15 amendments thereto: And provided further, That all such property included
16 in, added to or removed from the STAR bond project district established
17 pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of the STAR
18 bonds financing act: And provided further, That if such major amusement
19 park project or historic theater uses state sales tax financing pursuant to
20 K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, such project shall be subject
21 to the requirements of K.S.A. 12-17,176, and amendments thereto: And
22 provided further, That in the event that the city or county shall default in
23 the payment of any STAR bonds payable from revenues described in
24 K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)(1), and amendments thereto, no public funds shall be
25 used to pay the holders thereof except as specifically authorized by the
26 STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That copies of all
27 retailers' sales, use and transient guest tax returns filed with the secretary
28 of revenue in connection with such major amusement park project shall be
29 subject to the provisions of K.S.A. 12-17,174, and amendments thereto.
30 (2) For purposes of this subsection:
31 (A) "Amusement rides" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 44-
32 1601, and amendments thereto, and includes such amusement rides and
33 further include buildings necessary to house and operate such amusement
34 park rides, buildings immediately adjacent and attached to such
35 amusement park rides and a building necessary to house a conference
36 center within the major amusement park area.
37 (B) "Major amusement park" means a project with amusement rides
38 and related attractions and upon which the secretary has made a finding
39 that capital improvements of not less than $100,000,000 will be built in the
40 state to construct the major amusement park.
41 (C) "Major amusement park area" means an area containing a major
42 amusement park.
43 (i) On July 1, 2025, or as soon thereafter as moneys are available, the

S Sub Sub HB 2007 102
1 director of accounts and reports shall transfer $4,000,000 from the
2 American rescue plan – state fiscal relief – federal fund (252-00-3756) of
3 the governor's department to the American rescue plan state relief – federal
4 fund (300-00-3756) of the department of commerce.
5 (j) On July 1, 2025, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
6 $7,000,000 from the state general fund to the attracting powerful economic
7 expansion payroll incentive fund (300-00-2943) established by K.S.A.
8 2024 Supp. 74-50,316, and amendments thereto.
9 (k) On July 1, 2025, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
10 $3,000,000 from the state general fund to the attracting powerful economic
11 expansion new employee training and education fund (300-00-2944)
12 established by K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 74-50,318, and amendments thereto.

16 2024 Supp. 74-50,323, and amendments thereto.

18 DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE

33 park project or historic theater shall be eligible for financing by special
34 obligation bonds payable from revenues described by K.S.A. 12-17,169(a)
35 (1), and amendments thereto: And provided further, That such city or
36 county is authorized to issue such special obligation bonds in one or more
37 series to finance the undertaking of such major amusement park project or
38 historic theater in accordance with the provisions of the STAR bonds
39 financing act: And provided further, That the secretary shall review the
40 STAR bond project plan and determine whether to approve such plan in

42 further, That any special obligation bonds issued to finance the major
43 amusement park project or historic theater shall be subject to the

S Sub Sub HB 2007 103
1 provisions of the STAR bonds financing act: And provided further, That
2 such major amusement park and historic theater costs shall be considered
3 project costs for the purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and amendments
4 thereto: And provided further, That a major amusement park area shall be
5 considered an eligible area for purposes of K.S.A. 12-17,162, and
6 amendments thereto: And provided further, That all such property included
7 in, added to or removed from the STAR bond project district established
8 pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the provisions of the STAR
9 bonds financing act: And provided further, That if such major amusement
10 park project or historic theater uses state sales tax financing pursuant to
11 K.S.A. 12-17,169, and amendments thereto, such project shall be subject
12 to the requirements of K.S.A. 12-17,176, and amendments thereto: And

22 (A) "Amusement rides" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 44-

3 Sec. 72.
4 KANSAS HOUSING RESOURCES CORPORATION
5 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
6 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all
7 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
8 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
9 not exceed the following:
10 State housing trust fund (175-00-7370-7000)...................................No limit
11 Provided, That all expenditures from the state housing trust fund shall be
12 made by the Kansas housing resources corporation for the purposes of
13 administering and supporting housing programs of the Kansas housing
14 resources corporation as authorized by K.S.A. 74-8959, and amendments
15 thereto, and this section: Provided further, That of the moneys
16 appropriated in the state housing trust fund and identified as moneys for
17 the rural housing revolving loan program, as authorized by section 28 of
18 chapter 81 of the 2022 Session Laws of Kansas, or identified as moneys
19 for the housing revolving loan program, as authorized by section 77 of
20 chapter 82 of the 2023 Session Laws of Kansas, expenditures may be
21 made by the above agency from such identified moneys in such fund for
22 fiscal year 2026 for loans to a local unit of government, political
23 subdivision of the state, not-for-profit organizations focused on housing
24 development, for-profit or not-for-profit builder or developer for moderate
25 and low-income housing development, including infrastructure necessary
26 to support such development: And provided further, That at least 50% of
27 such expenditures shall be used in rural communities: And provided
28 further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of any statute to the contrary,
29 a local government or political subdivision of the state is hereby
30 authorized to enter into loan agreements under this program: And provided
31 further, That the provisions and restrictions of the cash basis and budget
32 laws of this state shall not apply to any loan received by a local
33 government or political subdivision under this program: And provided
34 further, That notwithstanding the provisions of any statute, the interest rate
35 for a loan to any not-for-profit organization focused on housing
36 development shall be equal to the average interest rate of certificates of
37 deposit in Kansas financial institutions in June 2025, as determined by the
38 state treasurer.

37 Sec. 76.
38 DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT –
39 DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH
40 (a) On the effective date of this act, of the $5,940,415 appropriated
41 for the above agency for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section
42 77(a) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas from the state
43 general fund in the operating expenditures (including official hospitality)

S Sub Sub HB 2007 111
1 account (264-00-1000-0202), $1,386,165 is hereby lapsed.
2 (b) On the effective date of this act, of the $8,249,202 appropriated
3 for the above agency for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section
4 77(a) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas from the state
5 general fund in the aid to local units account (264-00-1000-0350), $10,419
6 is hereby lapsed.
7 (c) On the effective date of this act, of the $18,750,690 appropriated
8 for the above agency for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, by section
9 77(a) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas from the state
10 general fund in the aid to local units – primary health projects account
11 (264-00-1000-0460), $583,120 is hereby lapsed.
12 (d) On the effective date of this act, of the amount of moneys
13 appropriated and reappropriated for the above agency for the fiscal year
14 ending June 30, 2025, by section 77(a) of chapter 88 of the 2024 Session

16 replacement account (264-00-1000-0800), the sum of $429,385 is hereby
17 lapsed.
18 Sec. 77.

23 Operating expenditures (including official

26 (including official hospitality) account in excess of $100 as of June 30,
27 2025, is hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026.
28 Operating expenditures (including official
29 hospitality) – health (264-00-1000-0270)...............................$8,748,080
30 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in the operating expenditures
31 (including official hospitality) – health account in excess of $100 as of
32 June 30, 2025, is hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided
33 further, That expenditures in an amount of not to exceed $96,000 shall be
34 made by the above agency from such account for fiscal year 2026 to
35 provide for efforts to control and prevent transmission of tuberculosis,
36 including screening, diagnosis and treatment.
37 Aid to local units (264-00-1000-0350).........................................$8,249,202
38 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in the aid to local units account
39 in excess of $100 as of June 30, 2025, is hereby reappropriated for fiscal
40 year 2026: Provided further, That, except as provided in subsection (j), all
41 expenditures from this account for state financial assistance to local health
42 departments shall be in accordance with the formula prescribed by K.S.A.
43 65-241 through 65-246, and amendments thereto.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 112
1 Aid to local units – primary
2 health projects (264-00-1000-0460)......................................$18,750,690
3 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in the aid to local units –
4 primary health projects account in excess of $100 as of June 30, 2025, is
5 hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided further, That
6 prescription support expenditures shall be made from the aid to local units
7 – primary health projects account for: (1) Purchasing drug inventory under
8 section 340B of the federal public health service act for community health
9 center grantees and federally qualified health center look-alikes who
10 qualify; (2) increasing access to prescription drugs by subsidizing a
11 portion of the costs for the benefit of patients at section 340B participating
12 clinics on a sliding fee scale; and (3) expanding access to prescription
13 medication assistance programs by making expenditures to support
14 operating costs of assistance programs: And provided further, That funded
15 clinics shall be not-for-profit or publicly funded primary care clinics or
16 dental clinics, including federally qualified community health centers and
17 federally qualified community health center look-alikes, as defined by 42
18 U.S.C. § 330, that provide comprehensive primary healthcare or dental
19 services, offer sliding fee discounts based upon household income and
20 serve any person regardless of ability to pay and have a unique patient
21 panel that, at a minimum, represents the income-based disparities of the
22 community: And provided further, That policies determining patient
23 eligibility due to income or insurance status may be determined by each
24 community but must be clearly documented and posted: And provided
25 further, That of the moneys appropriated in the aid to local units – primary
26 health projects account, not less than $18,750,690 shall be distributed for
27 community-based primary care grants and services provided by the
28 community care network of Kansas.

32 reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided further, That during the fiscal
33 year ending June 30, 2026, expenditures shall be made by the above
34 agency from the infant and toddler program account in the amount of
35 $8,000,000 for the purposes of aid to local units and other assistance: And
36 provided further, That such moneys shall not be expended for

17 Sec. 83.
18 KANSAS DEPARTMENT FOR
19 AGING AND DISABILITY SERVICES
20 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the state general
21 fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the following:
22 Mental health intervention team pilot (039-00-1000-0160).......$16,034,722
23 Provided, That any unencumbered balance in the mental health
24 intervention team pilot account in excess of $100 as of June 30, 2025, is
25 hereby reappropriated for fiscal year 2026: Provided further, That
26 expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such account during
27 fiscal year 2026 in an amount of $1,500,000 for qualified schools: And
28 provided further, That expenditures shall be made by the above agency
29 from such account during fiscal year 2026, to establish the mental health
30 intervention team program as provided by the provisions of this proviso:
31 (1) And provided further, That such school district program shall
32 be a continuation of the mental health intervention team pilot program first
33 established pursuant to section 1 of chapter 57 of the 2018 Session Laws
34 of Kansas and K.S.A. 72-9943, and amendments thereto, and continued
35 and expanded through subsequent appropriation acts of the legislature:
36 And provided further, That the purposes of the mental health intervention
37 team program are to: Provide greater access to behavioral health services
38 for students enrolled in kindergarten or any of the grades one through 12
39 and establish a coherent structure between school districts and mental
40 health intervention team providers to optimize scarce behavioral health
41 resources and workforce; identify students, communicate with families and
42 link students and their families to the statewide behavioral health systems
43 and resources within the network of mental health intervention team

S Sub Sub HB 2007 144
1 providers; alleviate the shortage of staff with specialized degrees or
2 training such as school counselors, psychologists and social workers and
3 reduce the competition for such staff between school districts and other
4 private and governmental service providers to provide broader-based and
5 collaborative services to students, especially in rural districts that do not
6 have enough students to justify a full-time staff position; provide and
7 coordinate mental health services to students throughout the calendar year,
8 not only during school hours over nine months of the school year; and
9 reduce barriers that families experience to access mental health services
10 and maintain consistency for a child to attend recurring sessions and
11 coordination between the child's classroom schedule and the provision of
12 such services: And provided further, That the program shall focus on the
13 following students: Any student who has been adjudicated as a child in
14 need of care and is in the custody of the secretary for children and families
15 or has been referred for a families first program or family preservation
16 program; and any other student who is in need of mental health support
17 services: And provided further, That the secretary for aging and disability
18 services shall appoint a mental health intervention team program manager
19 and, within the limits of appropriations therefor, such additional staff as
20 necessary to support such manager: And provided further, That the above
21 agency shall oversee and implement the mental health intervention team
22 program in accordance with the requirements of this proviso and the
23 policies and procedures established by the above agency pursuant to this
24 proviso: And provided further, That during fiscal year 2026, the board of
25 education of a school district may apply to the above agency to establish or
26 maintain a mental health intervention team program within such school
27 district: And provided further, That the application shall be in such form
28 and manner as the above agency requires and submitted at a time
29 determined and specified by such agency: And provided further, That each
30 application submitted by a school district shall specify the mental health
31 intervention team provider that the school intends to coordinate with to
32 provide school-based services to students who need assistance during the
33 applicable school year: And provided further, That the school district shall
34 provide notice to the mental health intervention team provider, as soon as
35 they are able, of their intent to partner for the following school year: And
36 provided further, That the above agency shall establish an application
37 review committee that shall include representatives from mental health
38 intervention team providers and the department of education: And
39 provided further, That if a school district and mental health intervention
40 team provider are approved to establish or maintain a mental health
41 intervention team program, the school district shall enter into a
42 memorandum of understanding with a partnering mental health
43 intervention team provider: And provided further, That if the school district

S Sub Sub HB 2007 145
1 chooses to partner with more than one mental health intervention team
2 provider, the school district shall enter into a separate memorandum of
3 understanding with each such mental health intervention team provider:
4 And provided further, That the above agency may establish requirements
5 for a memorandum of understanding, including contractual provisions that
6 are required to be included in each memorandum of understanding and that
7 are optional and subject to agreement between the school district and the
8 mental health intervention team provider: And provided further, That each
9 memorandum of understanding shall be submitted to the above agency for
10 final approval: And provided further, That the above agency may authorize
11 another category of provider other than a mental health intervention team
12 provider to serve as a partnering provider under the mental health
13 intervention team program pursuant to this proviso: And provided further,
14 That such category of provider shall provide the required services and
15 otherwise meet the requirements of a partnering mental health intervention
16 team provider under this proviso: And provided further, That if the above
17 agency authorizes another category of provider other than a mental health
18 intervention team provider, such agency shall provide notification of this
19 decision to the mental health intervention team provider that provides
20 services in that county: And provided further, That, subject to
21 appropriations therefor, a school district and mental health intervention
22 team provider that have been approved by the above agency to establish or
23 maintain a mental health intervention team program shall be eligible to
24 receive a mental health intervention team program grant and a mental
25 health intervention team provider pass-through grant: Provided, however,
26 That the amount of a school district's mental health intervention team
27 program grant shall be determined in each school year by calculating the
28 total amount of the salary and fringe benefits paid by the school district to
29 each school liaison: And provided further, That the amount of a school
30 district's mental health intervention team provider pass-through grant shall
31 be an amount equal to 35% of the amount of the school district's mental
32 health intervention team grant: And provided further, That moneys
33 provided to a school district for the mental health intervention team
34 provider pass-through grant shall be paid to any mental health intervention
35 team provider that partners with the school district: And provided further,
36 That if the amount of appropriations are insufficient to pay in full the
37 amount of all grants school districts are entitled to receive for the school
38 year, the above agency shall prorate the amount appropriated among all
39 districts: And provided further, That the above agency shall be responsible
40 for the allocation and distribution of grants in accordance with
41 appropriation acts: And provided further, That the above agency may make
42 grant payments in installments and may provide for payments in advance
43 or by way of reimbursement and may make any necessary adjustments for

S Sub Sub HB 2007 146
1 any overpayment to a school district: And provided further, That the above
2 agency shall not award any grant to a school district unless such district
3 has entered into a memorandum of understanding with a partnering mental
4 health intervention team provider in accordance with this proviso: And
5 provided further, That any remaining appropriations that were not
6 allocated to the mental health intervention team program shall provide
7 funding in the form of grants from the above agency to the association of
8 mental health intervention team providers of Kansas to fund training for
9 school districts participating in the mental health intervention team
10 program pursuant to this proviso: And provided further, That the above
11 agency shall seek advice from mental health intervention team providers
12 prior to awarding any grant under this subsection: And provided further,
13 That the above agency may waive the requirement that a school district
14 employ a school liaison and may instead authorize a mental health
15 intervention team provider that partners with the school district to employ
16 a school liaison: And provided further, That such waiver shall only be
17 granted by the above agency in limited circumstances: And provided
18 further, That a school district that is granted a waiver pursuant to this
19 proviso shall continue to be eligible to receive the mental health
20 intervention team program grant and the mental health intervention team
21 provider pass-through grant authorized pursuant to this proviso: And
22 provided further, That the amount of the mental health intervention team
23 program grant shall be determined in the same manner as provided under
24 this proviso as though the school liaison was employed by such school
25 district: And provided further, That upon receipt of any moneys awarded
26 pursuant to the mental health intervention team program grant to any such
27 school district, the school district shall direct payment of such amount to
28 the mental health intervention team provider that employs the school
29 liaison: And provided further, That on or before January 12, 2026, the
30 above agency shall prepare and submit a report on the mental health
31 intervention team program for the preceding school year to the house of
32 representatives standing committees on appropriations, social services
33 budget and health and human services, or their successor committees, and
34 the senate standing committees on ways and means, ways and means
35 subcommittee on human services and public health and welfare, or their
36 successor committees: And provided further, That such report shall provide
37 a summary of the program, including, but not limited to, the school
38 districts that applied to participate or continued participating under the
39 program, the mental health intervention team providers, the grant amount
40 each such school district received and the payments made by school
41 districts from the mental health intervention team program fund of each
42 school district: And provided further, That the staff required for the
43 establishment and maintenance of a mental health intervention team

S Sub Sub HB 2007 147
1 program shall include a combination of one or more behavioral health
2 liaisons employed by the school district and one or more case managers
3 and therapists licensed by the behavioral sciences regulatory board who
4 are employed by the partnering mental health intervention team provider:
5 And provided further, That all staff working together under a school
6 district's program shall be known as the mental health intervention team of
7 the school district: And provided further, That the school district and the
8 mental health intervention team provider shall cooperate and work
9 together to identify needs specific to the students in the school district, and
10 the families of such students and shall develop an action plan to implement
11 a school-based program that is tailored to such needs: And provided
12 further, That a school district that participates in the program shall employ
13 one or more school liaisons who will help students in need and coordinate
14 services between the school district, the student, the student's family and
15 the mental health intervention team provider: And provided further, That a
16 school liaison shall have a bachelor's degree in any field of study: And
17 provided further, That a school liaison's roles and responsibilities include,
18 but are not limited to: Identifying appropriate student referrals for the team
19 to engage with; act as a liaison between the school district and the mental
20 health intervention team provider and be the primary point of contact for
21 communications between the school district and the mental health
22 intervention team provider; assist with mental health intervention team
23 provider staff understanding of the school district's system and procedures
24 including the school calendar, professional development, drills and crisis
25 plan protocols; triage prospective student referrals and help decide how to
26 prioritize interventions; help the mental health intervention team provider
27 and other school personnel understand the roles and responsibilities of the
28 mental health intervention team; facilitate communications and
29 connections between families of identified students and the mental health
30 intervention team provider's staff; coordinate a student's treatment
31 schedule with building administrators and classroom teachers to optimize
32 the clinical therapist's productivity; troubleshoot problems that arise and
33 work with the mental health intervention team provider to resolve such
34 problems; track and compile outcomes to monitor the effectiveness of the
35 program; maintain and update the department of education mental health
36 intervention team database as directed by the above agency and required
37 by this section; follow up with child welfare contacts if a student has
38 moved schools to get the child's educational history; be an active part of
39 the school intervention team and relay information back to mental health
40 intervention team provider staff, including student observations,
41 intervention feedback from teachers, communications with family and
42 other relevant information; work with school administration to identify and
43 provide confidential space for a mental health intervention team provider

S Sub Sub HB 2007 148
1 therapist; assist in planning continuity of care through summer services;
2 and submit an annual report to the above agency on how the liaison
3 complied with the required roles and responsibilities: And provided
4 further, That within the scope of employment by a school district, an
5 individual employed as a school liaison shall primarily perform roles and
6 responsibilities that are related to the school liaison position as described
7 in this section: And provided further, That once the initial referral has been
8 completed for a student, all relevant information shall be entered into the
9 database within 14 calendar days: And provided further, That a mental
10 health intervention team provider that partners with a school district shall
11 employ one or more therapists licensed by the behavioral sciences
12 regulatory board who will collaborate with the school district to assist
13 students in need and provide services to such students under the program:
14 And provided further, That a therapist's roles and responsibilities under the
15 program include, but are not limited to: Assist the school liaison with the
16 identification of appropriate student referrals to the program; triage student
17 referrals with the school liaison to prioritize treatment interventions for
18 identified students; work with the school liaison to connect with families
19 or child welfare contacts to obtain consent to commence treatment;
20 conduct a clinical assessment of the identified student and make
21 appropriate treatment recommendations; engage with the student, family
22 or child welfare contacts in clinical interventions as identified on the
23 treatment plan and provide individual and family therapy; administer
24 scales or tests to detect areas of concern with depression, anxiety, self-
25 harm or other areas as identified; make referrals to other treatment
26 modalities as appropriate; communicate educationally appropriate
27 information to the school liaison, such as interventions and strategies for
28 use by classroom and school staff; gather outcome data to monitor the
29 effectiveness of the program; coordinate with the case manager to identify
30 ways to support the student and family; provide therapy services as
31 determined by the students' treatment plan; and maintain the treatment
32 plan and necessary treatment protocols required by the mental health
33 intervention team provider: And provided further, That a mental health
34 intervention team provider that partners with a school district shall employ
35 one or more case managers who will collaborate with the school district to
36 assist students in need and to coordinate services under the program: And
37 provided further, That a case manager's roles and responsibilities under the
38 program include, but are not limited to: Work with the school liaison and
39 clinical therapist to identify students and triage priorities for treatment;
40 provide outreach to students, families and child welfare contacts to help
41 engage in treatment; participate in the treatment planning process;
42 communicate with the school liaison and other school district personnel
43 about student needs, interventions and progress; help maintain

S Sub Sub HB 2007 149
1 communication between all entities, including the family, student, school,
2 clinical therapist, child welfare contacts and the community; maintain the
3 treatment plan and necessary treatment protocols required by the mental
4 health intervention team provider; make referrals to appropriate
5 community resources; help reconnect students and families when they are
6 not following through with the treatment process; help families negotiate
7 barriers to treatment; and engage with the student in the classroom, the
8 home or the community to help build skills wherever needed: And
9 provided further, That each school district that receives moneys for the
10 mental health intervention team program grant or the mental health
11 intervention team provider pass-through grant awarded pursuant to this
12 proviso shall credit the moneys to a mental health intervention team
13 program fund created by such school district: And provided further, That
14 moneys in such fund shall be used by a school district to: Pay for the
15 expenditures that are attributable to the salary and fringe benefits of any
16 school liaison employed by the school district pursuant to the mental
17 health intervention team program; and provide payment to each partnering
18 mental health intervention team provider in an amount equal to the mental
19 health intervention team provider pass-through grant received by the
20 school district: And provided further, That the school district shall keep
21 separate accounting records for the school liaison expenditures and the
22 pass-through grants to mental health intervention team providers: And
23 provided further, That the above agency shall publish on its website an
24 aggregated report of outcomes achieved, numbers served and associated
25 information by the mental health intervention team program: And provided
26 further, That the above agency shall establish a crisis hotline, available 24
27 hours a day, seven days a week, that individuals receiving services from
28 the mental health intervention team program may access outside of the
29 hours that such individuals are receiving services: And provided further,
30 That such hotline shall be established for the purposes of providing
31 information sharing and communications regarding crisis coordination and
32 emergency response services:
33 (2) And provided further, That such qualified school district
34 program shall be established and implemented by the board as established
35 in this paragraph: And provided further, That the board shall be appointed
36 by the secretary as follows: (A) A school psychologist employed by a
37 qualified school; (B) a school administrator employed by a qualified
38 school; (C) a mental health professional employed by a community mental
39 health center; (D) a mental health professional employed by a federally
40 qualified health center; (E) a representative of the state board of education;
41 (F) a representative of the above agency; and (G) a parent or guardian of a
42 qualified school student: And provided further, That the board shall
43 establish a plan, including specified criteria, for the allocation of moneys

S Sub Sub HB 2007 150
1 to qualified schools for the establishment and maintenance of mental
2 health intervention teams: And provided further, That such teams will
3 provide timely support and resources to students facing mental health
4 issues in order to promote a healthier learning environment: And provided
5 further, That the board shall review the criteria for school district funding
6 as provided in paragraph (1) and determine which such criteria will work
7 best for the qualified schools: And provided further, That such criteria may
8 include student population size, demonstrated need for mental health
9 support and the availability of qualified staff: And provided further, That
10 any qualified school seeking funding for mental health intervention teams
11 shall submit a proposal for funding to the board: And provided further,
12 That the board shall evaluate each proposal based on the criteria
13 established by the board: And provided further, That the board shall make
14 recommendations to the secretary on the allocation of funding and the
15 secretary shall allocate funding for qualified schools based on such
16 recommendations: And provided further, That the board shall oversee the
17 implementation of the qualified school's mental health intervention teams:
18 And provided further, That the board shall review the criteria for school
19 district reporting, monitoring and evaluating as provided in paragraph (1)
20 and determine which such criteria will work best for the qualified schools:
21 And provided further, That the board shall establish such reporting,
22 monitoring and evaluating to ensure that the mental health intervention
23 teams effectively meet the needs of students and adhere to best practices in
24 mental healthcare program service delivery: And provided further, That on
25 or before January 12, 2026, the above agency shall prepare and submit a
26 report summarizing the mental health intervention team program for
27 qualified schools to the house of representatives standing committees on
28 appropriations, social services budget and health and human services, or
29 their successor committees, and the senate standing committees on ways
30 and means, ways and means subcommittee on human services and public
31 health and welfare, or their successor committees: And provided further,
32 That the board shall provide resources, training and support to qualified
33 schools and such school's mental health intervention teams, including
34 access to professional development opportunities, educational materials
35 and networking opportunities with other qualified schools and mental
36 health organizations: and
37 (3) And provided further, That as used in this proviso: (A)
38 "Mental health intervention team provider" means a center organized
39 pursuant to article 40 of chapter 19 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, and
40 amendments thereto, a mental health clinic organized pursuant to article 2
41 of chapter 65 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, and amendments thereto,
42 or a federally qualified health center as defined by section 1905(l)(2)(B) of
43 the federal social security act: And provided further, That "mental health

S Sub Sub HB 2007 151
1 intervention team provider" includes other provider categories as
2 authorized by the above agency to serve as a partnering provider under the
3 mental health intervention team program pursuant to this proviso: And
4 provided further, That a provider under this proviso shall provide services,
5 including: Support for students available 24 hours a day, seven days a
6 week; person-centered treatment planning; and outpatient mental health
7 services; (B) "school district" means a school district as defined in K.S.A.
8 72-5132, and amendments thereto; and (C) "qualified school" means any
9 nonpublic school that provides education to elementary or secondary
10 students and is accredited by the state board or a national or regional
11 accrediting agency that is recognized by the state board for the purpose of
12 satisfying the teaching performance assessment for professional licensure
13 or is working in good faith toward such accreditation.

1 (b) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following

S Sub Sub HB 2007 160
1 supplemental healthcare services agency charged the healthcare facility for
2 each individual agency employee category and the supplemental
3 healthcare services agency paid to employees in each individual employee
4 category: And provided further, That as used in this subsection,
5 "supplemental healthcare services agency" means a person, firm,
6 corporation, partnership or association engaged in for-hire business of
7 providing or procuring temporary employment in healthcare facilities for
8 healthcare personnel, including a temporary nursing staffing agency, or
9 operates a digital website or digital smartphone application that facilitates
10 the provision of the engagement of healthcare personnel and accepts
11 requests for healthcare personnel through a digital website or digital
12 smartphone application: Provided, however, That a "supplemental
13 healthcare services agency" shall not include an individual who engages
14 on their own behalf or to provide services on a temporary basis to
15 healthcare facilities or a home health agency: And provided further, That as
16 used in this subsection, "temporary nursing staffing agency" means a
17 person, firm, corporation, partnership or association doing business within
18 the state that supplies, on a temporary basis, registered nurses or licensed
19 practical nurses to a hospital, nursing home or other facility requiring such
20 services.

33 (n) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the

41 clinic any community behavioral health center licensed by such agency
42 that provides the following services: Crisis services; screening, assessment
43 and diagnosis, including risk assessment; person-centered treatment

S Sub Sub HB 2007 167
1 planning; outpatient mental health and substance use services; primary
2 care screening and monitoring of key indicators of health risks; targeted
3 case management; psychiatric rehabilitation services; peer support and
4 family supports; medication-assisted treatment; assertive community
5 treatment; and community-based mental healthcare for military
6 servicemembers and veterans.
7 (o) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the
8 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
9 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or from any special
10 revenue fund or funds, as authorized by this or any other appropriation act
11 of the 2025 regular session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made
12 by such agency from such moneys to submit a report on a quarterly basis,
13 in collaboration with the Kansas department of health and environment, to
14 the Robert G. (Bob) Bethell joint committee on home and community
15 based services regarding the home and community-based services brain
16 injury waiver, including the:
17 (1) Number of members enrolled in such waiver at the end of the
18 month prior to the committee meeting;
19 (2) unduplicated number of such members over the course of the
20 calendar year;
21 (3) number of such members receiving services for a period longer
22 than 2 years and longer than 4 years;
23 (4) number of such members who did not receive services within a
24 period of 60, 90 or 120 or more days after being enrolled;
25 (5) number of such members who did not receive a specific waiver
26 service within a period of 30, 60, 90 or 120 or more days prior to the date
27 such member was officially unenrolled from such waiver;
28 (6) amount of the per-member, per-month enhanced dollar rate
29 provided to a managed care organization for each member enrolled in such
30 waiver;
31 (7) total number of members enrolled in the waiver disaggregated by
32 county and the per capita enrollment in such waiver disaggregated by
33 county; and
34 (8) agency's progress toward new policy implementation.
35 (p) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the
36 other purposes for which the above agency may make expenditures from
37 moneys appropriated from the state general fund or in any special revenue

43 guidelines for other adult care homes, as defined in K.S.A. 39-923, and

S Sub Sub HB 2007 168
1 amendments thereto: Provided, That any such guidelines shall be
2 compatible with rules established by the United States centers for
3 medicare and medicaid services.

20 disability: Provided, That such report shall be submitted to the senate
21 committee on public health and welfare, the appropriate subcommittee of
22 the senate committee on ways and means, the house of representatives
23 committee on health and human services and the house of representatives
24 committee on social services budget.
25 (s) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the
26 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
27 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special
28 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026, as authorized by this or any
29 other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature,
30 expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such moneys during
31 fiscal year 2026, for the purpose of reviewing the overall costs of
32 providing services within the intellectual and developmental disability
33 service system and making recommendations to the legislature for a
34 method to make regular rate adjustments for such services based on
35 inflationary indexes.
36 (t) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, notwithstanding the
37 provisions of any other statute, in addition to the other purposes for which
38 expenditures may be made from moneys appropriated for the above
39 agency from the state general fund or any special revenue fund or funds
40 for fiscal year 2026, as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the
41 2025 regular session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made by the
42 above agency from such moneys to submit a report on how much funding
43 goes to each community developmental disability organization to provide

S Sub Sub HB 2007 169
1 services that are not reimbursable from other funding sources, including
2 what services are provided and what percentage of funds go to each
3 service to the senate committee on ways and means human services
4 subcommittee and the house of representatives committee on social
5 services budget on or before January 12, 2026.
6 (u) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the
7 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
8 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or from any special
9 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026, as authorized by this or any
10 other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature,
11 expenditures shall be made by such agency from such moneys to require
12 all assisted living facilities, residential healthcare facilities, home plus and
13 boarding care homes, as such terms are defined in K.S.A. 39-923, and
14 amendments thereto, during fiscal year 2026 to submit a report to the
15 secretary for aging and disability services upon the completion of every
16 involuntary transfer or discharge of a resident pursuant to K.A.R. 26-39-
17 102(d) and (f): Provided, however, That such reports shall include no
18 personally identifiable information: Provided further, That such report
19 shall include: (1) The date when notice of transfer or discharge was
20 provided; (2) the date when the resident left the facility; (3) the type of
21 facility where the resident was transferred or discharged; (4) the reason
22 that required the transfer or discharge of the resident pursuant to K.A.R.
23 26-39-102(d); (5) if the resident was transferred or discharged pursuant to
24 K.A.R. 26-39-102(f), the reason that required such transfer or discharge;
25 (6) if the resident filed a complaint regarding the notice of transfer or
26 discharge; and (7) any other relevant information required by the secretary:
27 And provided further, That any facility that fails to submit a report within
28 60 days of the completion of the transfer or discharge or resolution of a
29 formal complaint shall be subject to a civil penalty as provided in K.S.A.
30 39-946, and amendments thereto: And provided further, That the secretary
31 shall establish a system and collect data from the long-term care
32 ombudsman and such assisted living facilities, residential healthcare
33 facilities, home plus and boarding care homes on any involuntary transfers
34 or discharges pursuant to K.A.R. 26-39-102(d) and (f): And provided
35 further, That the secretary shall compile all such information and submit a
36 report to the house of representatives committees on social services
37 budget, health and human services and judiciary and the senate committees
38 on public health and welfare and ways and means on the first day of the
39 2026 regular session of the legislature.
40 (v) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
41 made by the above agency from moneys appropriated from the state
42 general fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year
43 2026 for the above agency as authorized by this or other appropriation act

S Sub Sub HB 2007 170
1 of the 2025 regular session of the legislature, expenditures may be made
2 by the above agency from such moneys for fiscal year 2026 for the
3 administrative costs incurred by the community developmental disabilities
4 organizations: Provided however, That such administrative costs shall not
5 exceed 2.4% of the total amount of moneys expended during fiscal year

31 receive home and community-based services pursuant to the physical
32 disability (PD) waiver to not more than 1,800 eligible individuals:

40 subcommittee of the committee on ways and means and the house of

42 and social services budget on or before January 12, 2026.
43 (y) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the

S Sub Sub HB 2007 171
1 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency

38 implement a virtual math program that shall be customized to Kansas
39 curriculum standards, be evidence-based, not impose any fee or cost upon
40 students, provide tutoring in multiple languages, provide professional
41 development for the implementation of the program and have been
42 implemented in other states during the preceding eight fiscal years: And

S Sub Sub HB 2007 182
1 program: And provided further, That the above agency shall recommend
2 that all school districts use such program: And provided further, That all

36 interests in water quality and quantity to the house of representatives
37 committee on appropriations, the senate committee on ways and means
38 and the governor on or before January 12, 2026.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 222
1 Kansas medical center for the purchase of health insurance for residents'

12 (c) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the chief executive
13 officer of the state board of regents, with the approval of the director of the
14 budget, may transfer any part of any item of appropriation in an account of
15 the state general fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, to another
16 item of appropriation in an account of the state general fund for fiscal year
17 2026. The chief executive officer of the state board of regents shall certify
18 each such transfer to the director of accounts and reports and shall transmit
19 a copy of each such certification to the director of legislative research. As
20 used in this subsection, "account" means any account of the state general
21 fund of the state board of regents, the university of Kansas, the university
22 of Kansas medical center, Kansas state university, Kansas state university
23 Salina, Kansas state university veterinary medical center, Kansas state
24 university extension systems and agriculture research programs, Wichita
25 state university, Emporia state university, Pittsburg state university and
26 Fort Hays state university.
27 (d) (1) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may
28 be made by any state educational institution from the moneys appropriated
29 from the state general fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for
30 fiscal year 2026 for such state educational institution, as authorized by this
31 or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature,
32 expenditures may be made by such state educational institution from
33 moneys appropriated from the state general fund or from any special
34 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 for the purposes of capital
35 improvement projects making energy and other conservation
36 improvements: Provided, That such capital improvement projects are
37 hereby approved for such state educational institution for the purposes of
38 K.S.A. 74-8905(b), and amendments thereto, and the authorization of
39 issuance of one or more series of bonds by the Kansas development
40 finance authority in accordance with that statute from time to time during
41 fiscal year 2026: Provided, however, That no such bonds shall be issued
42 until the state board of regents has first advised and consulted on any such
43 project with the joint committee on state building construction: Provided

S Sub Sub HB 2007 239
1 further, That the amount of the bond proceeds that may be utilized for any
2 such capital improvement project shall be subject to approval by the state
3 finance council acting on this matter, which is hereby characterized as a
4 matter of legislative delegation and subject to the guidelines prescribed in
5 K.S.A. 75-3711c(c), and amendments thereto, except that such approval
6 also may be given while the legislature is in session: And provided further,
7 That, in addition to such project costs, any such amount of bond proceeds
8 may include costs of issuance, capitalized interest and any required
9 reserves for the payment of principal and interest on such bonds: And
10 provided further, That all moneys received from the issuance of any such
11 bonds shall be deposited and accounted for as prescribed by applicable
12 bond covenants: And provided further, That payments relating to principal
13 and interest on such bonds shall be subject to and dependent upon annual
14 appropriations therefor to the state educational institution for which the
15 bonds are issued: And provided further, That each energy conservation
16 capital improvement project for which bonds are issued for financing
17 under this subsection shall be designed and completed in order to have
18 cost savings sufficient to be equal to or greater than the cost of debt service
19 on such bonds: And provided further, That the state board of regents shall
20 prepare and submit a report to the committee on appropriations of the
21 house of representatives and the committee on ways and means of the
22 senate on the savings attributable to energy conservation capital
23 improvements for which bonds are issued for financing under this
24 subsection at the beginning of the 2026 regular session of the legislature.
25 (2) As used in this subsection, "state educational institution" includes
26 each state educational institution as defined in K.S.A. 76-711, and
27 amendments thereto.
28 (e) (1) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may
29 be made by any postsecondary educational institution from moneys
30 appropriated from the state general fund or from any special revenue fund
31 or funds for fiscal year 2026 for such postsecondary educational institution
32 as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session
33 of the legislature, expenditures may be made by such postsecondary
34 educational institution from such moneys for fiscal year 2026 for the
35 purpose of deeming any person who is enrolled as a member of the
36 Kickapoo Tribe of Indians of the Kickapoo Reservation in Kansas, the
37 Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation, the Iowa Tribe of Kansas, the Sac and
38 Fox Nation of Missouri in Kansas and Nebraska or of indigenous nations
39 with historical connections to Kansas territories named in this subsection,
40 regardless of the residence of such person prior to admission at a
41 postsecondary educational institution, as a resident of this state for the
42 purpose of tuition and fees for attendance at any postsecondary
43 educational institution.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 240
1 (2) As used in this subsection:
2 (A) "Postsecondary educational institution" means the same as
3 defined in K.S.A. 74-3201b, and amendments thereto; and
4 (B) "indigenous nations with historical connections to Kansas
5 territories" means any federally recognized tribe containing one or more
6 references to the following tribal affiliations within such tribe's name:
7 Apache, Arapaho, Caddo, Cheyenne, Cherokee, Chickasaw, Chippewa and
8 Ojibwe (including Bay Mills), Choctaw, Comanche, Delaware, Iowa
9 (Ioway and Baxoje), Kaw (Kanza), Kickapoo, Kiowa, Miami, Missouria
10 (including Otoe-Missouria), Modoc, Muscogee (Creek, including Yuchi,

12 (Odawa), Potawatomi (Pottawatomi), Pawnee, Peoria, Ponca, Pueblo,

16 (c) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the secretary of
17 corrections, with the approval of the director of the budget, may transfer
18 any part of any item of appropriation for the fiscal year ending June 30,
19 2026, from the state general fund for the department of corrections or any
20 correctional institution or correctional facility under the general
21 supervision and management of the secretary of corrections to another
22 item of appropriation for fiscal year 2026 from the state general fund for
23 the department of corrections or any correctional institution or correctional
24 facility under the general supervision and management of the secretary of
25 corrections. The secretary of corrections shall certify each such transfer to
26 the director of accounts and reports and shall transmit a copy of each such
27 certification to the director of legislative research.
28 (d) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 75-3731, and
29 amendments thereto, or any other statute, the director of accounts and
30 reports shall accept for payment from the secretary of corrections any duly
31 authorized claim to be paid from the local jail payments account (521-00-
32 1000-0510) of the state general fund during fiscal year 2026 for costs
33 pursuant to K.S.A. 19-1930(b), and amendments thereto, even though such
34 claim is not submitted or processed for payment within the fiscal year in
35 which the service is rendered and whether or not the services were
36 rendered prior to the effective date of this act.
37 (e) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 75-3731, and
38 amendments thereto, or any other statute, the director of accounts and
39 reports shall accept for payment from the director of Kansas correctional
40 industries any duly authorized claim to be paid from the correctional
41 industries fund (522-00-6126-7300) during fiscal year 2026 for operating
42 or manufacturing costs even though such claim is not submitted or
43 processed for payment within the fiscal year in which the service is

S Sub Sub HB 2007 249
1 rendered and whether or not the services were rendered prior to the
2 effective date of this act. The director of Kansas correctional industries
3 shall provide to the director of the budget on or before September 15,
4 2026, a detailed accounting of all such payments made from the
5 correctional industries fund during fiscal year 2026.
6 (f) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the secretary of
7 corrections, with the approval of the director of the budget, may make
8 transfers from the correctional industries fund (522-00-6126-7300) to the
9 department of corrections – general fees fund (521-00-2427-2450). The
10 secretary of corrections shall certify each such transfer to the director of
11 accounts and reports and shall transmit a copy of each such certification to
12 the director of legislative research.
13 (g) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all expenditures
14 made by the department of corrections from the correctional industries
15 fund (522-00-6126-7300) shall be made on budget for all purposes of state
16 accounting and budgeting for the department of corrections.
17 (h) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 75-52,164, and
18 amendments thereto, or any other statute, during fiscal year 2026, the
19 director of accounts and reports shall transfer the amount certified
20 pursuant to K.S.A. 75-52,164(b), and amendments thereto, from each
21 account of the state general fund of a state agency that has been
22 determined by the secretary of corrections to be actual or projected cost
23 savings to the evidence-based programs account of the state general fund
24 of the department of corrections: Provided, That the secretary of
25 corrections shall transmit a copy of each such certification to the director
26 of legislative research.

6 (c) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the director of the
7 budget and the director of legislative research shall consult periodically
8 and review the balance credited to and the estimated receipts to be credited
9 to the fire marshal fee fund (234-00-2330-2000) during fiscal year 2026,
10 and, upon a finding by the director of the budget in consultation with the
11 director of legislative research that the total of the unencumbered balance
12 and estimated receipts to be credited to the fire marshal fee fund during
13 fiscal year 2026 are insufficient to fund the budgeted expenditures and
14 transfers from the fire marshal fee fund for fiscal year 2026 in accordance
15 with the provisions of appropriation acts, the director of the budget shall
16 certify such finding to the director of accounts and reports. Upon receipt of
17 any such certification, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
18 the amount of moneys from the emergency response fund (234-00-2589)
19 to the fire marshal fee fund that is required, in accordance with the
20 certification by the director of the budget under this subsection, to fund the
21 budgeted expenditures and transfers from the fire marshal fee fund for the
22 remainder of fiscal year 2026 in accordance with the provisions of
23 appropriation acts, as specified by the director of the budget pursuant to
24 such certification.
25 (d) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the director of the
26 budget and the director of legislative research shall consult periodically
27 and review the balance credited to and the estimated receipts to be credited
28 to the fire marshal fee fund (234-00-2330-2000) and any other resources
29 available to the fire marshal fee fund during the fiscal year 2026, and,
30 upon a finding by the director of the budget in consultation with the
31 director of legislative research that the total of the unencumbered balance
32 and estimated receipts to be credited to the fire marshal fee fund during
33 fiscal year 2026 are insufficient to meet in full the estimated expenditures
34 for fiscal year 2026 as they become due to meet the financial obligations
35 imposed by law on the fire marshal fee fund as a result of a cash flow
36 shortfall, within the authorized budgeted expenditures in accordance with
37 the provisions of appropriation acts, the director of the budget is
38 authorized and directed to certify such finding to the director of accounts
39 and reports. Upon receipt of any such certification, the director of accounts
40 and reports shall transfer the amount of money specified in such
41 certification from the state general fund to the fire marshal fee fund in
42 order to maintain the cash flow of the fire marshal fee fund for such
43 purposes for fiscal year 2026. The aggregate amount of such transfers

S Sub Sub HB 2007 258
1 during fiscal year 2026 pursuant to this subsection shall not exceed
2 $500,000. Within one year from the date of each such transfer to the fire
3 marshal fee fund pursuant to this subsection, the director of accounts and
4 reports shall transfer the amount equal to the amount transferred from the
5 state general fund to the fire marshal fee fund from the fire marshal fee
6 fund to the state general fund in accordance with a certification for such
7 purpose by the director of the budget. At the same time as the director of
8 the budget transmits any certification under this subsection to the director
9 of accounts and reports during fiscal year 2026, the director of the budget
10 shall transmit a copy of such certification to the director of legislative
11 research.

31 credited to the general fees fund, except as otherwise provided by law:
32 Provided further, That, notwithstanding the provisions of article 66 of

34 addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the
35 above agency from the general fees fund, expenditures shall be made by

37 trigger lock, of a part-time state law enforcement officer, who has 10 years
38 or more of service, to such officer, subject to the following: (1) Such
39 officer is resigning; (2) the sale of such personal sidearm shall be for the
40 amount equal to the total of the fair market value of the sidearm, as fixed
41 by the superintendent, plus the cost of the trigger lock; and (3) no sale of a
42 personal sidearm shall be made to any resigning officer unless the
43 superintendent determines that the employment record and performance

S Sub Sub HB 2007 260
1 evaluations of each such officer are satisfactory: And provided further,
2 That all proceeds from the sale of personal sidearms and trigger locks shall
3 be deposited in the state treasury in accordance with the provisions of
4 K.S.A. 75-4215, and amendments thereto, and shall be credited to the
5 general fees fund.

1 similar investigatory purposes; (3) conducting investigations and related

41 (b) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
42 made by the emergency medical services board from the emergency
43 medical services operating fund (206-00-2326-4000) for fiscal year 2026,

S Sub Sub HB 2007 271
1 as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session
2 of the legislature, expenditures may be made by the emergency medical
3 services board from the emergency medical services operating fund for
4 fiscal year 2026 for the purpose of implementing a grant program for
5 emergency medical services training and educational assistance for
6 persons in underserved areas: Provided, That when issuing such grants,
7 first priority shall be given to ambulance services submitting applications
8 seeking grants to pay the cost of recruiting volunteers and cost of the
9 initial courses of training for emergency medical service providers:
10 Provided further, That the second priority shall be given to ambulance
11 services submitting applications seeking grants to pay the cost of
12 continuing education for emergency medical service providers: And
13 provided further, That the third priority shall be given to ambulance
14 services submitting applications seeking grants to pay the cost of
15 education for emergency medical service providers who are obtaining a
16 postsecondary education degree for the purpose of becoming instructors of
17 emergency medical services educational courses.
18 (c) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
19 made by the emergency medical services board from the moneys
20 appropriated from the state general fund or from any special revenue fund
21 or funds for the emergency medical services board for fiscal year 2026, as
22 authorized by this or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular
23 session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made by the emergency
24 medical services board from moneys appropriated from the state general
25 fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for the emergency medical
26 services board for fiscal year 2026 to require emergency medical services
27 agencies in each of the six EMS regions of the state to prepare and submit
28 a report of the expenditures made and moneys received in each of the EMS
29 regions that are related to the operation and administration of the Kansas
30 emergency medical services regional operations to the emergency medical
31 services board: Provided, That the report for each EMS region shall
32 specify and account for all moneys appropriated from the state treasury for
33 the emergency medical services board and disbursed to each such EMS
34 region for the operation of the education and training of emergency
35 medical service providers in each such EMS region.
36 (d) On July 1, 2025, and January 1, 2026, or as soon thereafter each
37 such date as moneys are available, the director of accounts and reports
38 shall transfer $150,000 from the emergency medical services operating
39 fund (206-00-2326-4000) to the educational incentive grant payment fund
40 (206-00-2396-2510) of the emergency medical services board.
41 (e) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the director of the
42 budget and the director of legislative research shall consult periodically
43 and review the balance credited to and the estimated receipts to be credited

S Sub Sub HB 2007 272
1 to the emergency medical services operating fund (206-00-2326-4000)
2 during fiscal year 2026, and, upon a finding by the director of the budget
3 in consultation with the director of legislative research that the total of the
4 unencumbered balance and estimated receipts to be credited to the
5 emergency medical services operating fund during fiscal year 2026 are
6 insufficient to fund the budgeted expenditures and transfers from the
7 emergency medical services operating fund for fiscal year 2026 in
8 accordance with the provisions of appropriation acts, the director of the
9 budget shall certify such funding to the director of accounts and reports.
10 Upon receipt of any such certification, the director of accounts and reports
11 shall transfer the amount of moneys from the education incentive grant
12 payment fund (206-00-2396-2510) to the emergency medical services
13 operating fund that is required, in accordance with the certification by the
14 director of the budget under this subsection, to fund the budgeted
15 expenditures and transfers from the emergency medical services operating
16 fund for the remainder of fiscal year 2026 in accordance with the
17 provisions of appropriation acts, as specified by the director of the budget
18 pursuant to such certification.
19 (f) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, if any EMS regional
20 council enters into a grant agreement with the emergency medical services
21 board, such council shall be required to submit pursuant to such grant
22 agreement a written report detailing and accounting for all expenditures
23 and receipts of such council during such fiscal year. The emergency
24 medical services board shall prepare a written report specifying and
25 accounting for all moneys received by and expended by each individual
26 council that has reported to the emergency medical services board pursuant
27 to such grant agreement and submit such report to the house of
28 representatives committee on appropriations and the senate committee on
29 ways and means on or before February 1, 2026.
30 Sec. 123.

35 general fund in the operating expenditures account (626-00-1000-0303),

8 Sec. 127.
9 STATE 911 BOARD
10 (a) There is appropriated for the above agency from the state general
11 fund for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the following:
12 Critical facility mapping grant program.......................................$2,000,000
13 Provided, That expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such
14 account during fiscal year 2026 to establish the critical facility mapping
15 grant program to facilitate efficient emergency response by public safety
16 agencies in the state of Kansas: Provided, That the purpose of such
17 program is to develop current and authoritative interior and exterior GIS
18 data for critical infrastructure in the state of Kansas: Provided further, That
19 the above agency shall administer the program to provide grants to Kansas
20 PSAPs, as defined in K.S.A. 12-5363, and amendments thereto, to develop
21 such GIS data that meets the requirements established by the agency in a
22 request for proposal: And provided further, That the program shall
23 prioritize grants to develop such GIS data for the following facilities in the
24 state in such order: (1) Any public or private elementary school or
25 secondary school; (2) any public postsecondary state educational
26 institution; (3) government buildings; (4) mass gathering sites; and (5)
27 healthcare facilities: And provided further, That any Kansas PSAP may
28 apply to the program for a grant for services to develop such GIS data for
29 one or more buildings in the service area of the PSAP, and such data shall:
30 (A) Be in formats that are compatible with and supported by public safety
31 applications commonly used by local, regional and state agencies within
32 Kansas; (B) be in formats capable of being printed, shared electronically
33 and, if requested, digitally integrated into interactive mobile platforms in
34 use; (C) be verified for accuracy by the entity producing the data by
35 conducting a walkthrough of the school facilities and grounds being
36 mapped; (D) be able to be represented as oriented true north, include a grid
37 with "x" and "y" coordinates for reference and include z-axis elevation
38 data; (E) include accurate floor plans overlaid on current, verified aerial
39 imagery of the facility grounds; (F) include site-specific labels that match
40 the structure of the buildings, including room labels, hallway names,
41 external door or stairwell numbers and the location of hazards, critical
42 utility locations, key boxes, automated external defibrillators and trauma
43 kits; (G) contain site-specific labels that match the facility grounds,

S Sub Sub HB 2007 275
1 including parking areas, athletic fields, surrounding roads and neighboring
2 properties; and (H) be provided to the facility owner and appropriate
3 public safety agencies at no additional cost beyond initial production with
4 ownership of the data being granted to the facilities to ensure that such
5 facilities can use the data permanently without further fees or restrictions.
6 (b) There is appropriated for the above agency from the following
7 special revenue fund or funds for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all
8 moneys now or hereafter lawfully credited to and available in such fund or
9 funds, except that expenditures other than refunds authorized by law shall
10 not exceed the following:
11 State 911 fund...................................................................................No limit
12 State 911 grant fund..........................................................................No limit
13 State 911 operations fund..................................................................No limit
