6 the operations of the central Kansas water bank: Provided, That such
7 evaluation shall include specific findings regarding the consumptive use
8 and potential impairment impacts involved with the use of safe deposit
9 accounts in the Rattlesnake Creek hydrologic unit: Provided further, That
10 the results of such evaluation shall be submitted to the house of
11 representatives committee on water and the senate committee on
12 agriculture and natural resources on or before January 12, 2026.
13 Sec. 129.
14 STATE FAIR BOARD
15 (a) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2025, in addition to the
16 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the above agency
17 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special
18 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2025 as authorized by section 136 of
19 chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas, this or any other
20 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature,
21 expenditures shall be made by the above agency from such moneys for
22 fiscal year 2025 to submit a report to the senate committee on agriculture
23 and natural resources and the house committee on agriculture and natural
24 resources budget during the 2026 regular session of the legislature
25 concerning the emergency command center at the state fair and plans from
26 the above agency to raise $1,750,000 in nonstate moneys to complete such
27 emergency command center.

1 appropriation for fiscal year 2026 from the state water plan fund for the

24 house of representatives agriculture and natural resources budget
25 committee and the appropriate chairperson of the subcommittee on natural
26 resources of the senate committee on ways and means.
27 (f) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, if it appears that the
28 resources are insufficient to meet in full the estimated expenditures as they
29 become due to meet the financial obligations imposed by law on the water
30 marketing fund (709-00-2255-2100) of the Kansas water office as a result
31 of a cash flow shortfall, the pooled money investment board is authorized
32 and directed to loan to the director of the Kansas water office a sufficient
33 amount or amounts of moneys to maintain the cash flow of the water
34 marketing fund upon approval of each such loan by the state finance
35 council acting on this matter, which is hereby characterized as a matter of
36 legislative delegation and subject to the guidelines prescribed in K.S.A.
37 75-3711c(c), and amendments thereto. No such loan shall be made unless
38 the terms have been approved by the director of the budget. A copy of the
39 terms of each such loan shall be submitted to the director of legislative
40 research. The pooled money investment board is authorized and directed to
41 use any moneys in the operating accounts, investment accounts or other
42 investments of the state of Kansas to provide the funds for each such loan.
43 Each such loan shall be repaid without interest within one year from the

S Sub Sub HB 2007 289
1 date of the loan.
2 (g) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, if it appears that the
3 resources are insufficient to meet in full the estimated expenditures as they
4 become due to meet the financial obligations imposed by law on the water
5 marketing fund (709-00-2255-2100) of the Kansas water office as a result
6 of increases in water rates, fees or charges imposed by the federal
7 government, the pooled money investment board is authorized and
8 directed to loan to the director of the Kansas water office a sufficient
9 amount or amounts of moneys to reimburse the water marketing fund for
10 increases in water rates, fees or charges imposed by the federal
11 government and to allow the Kansas water office to spread such increases
12 to consumers over a longer period, except that no such loan shall be made
13 unless the terms thereof have been approved by the state finance council
14 acting on this matter, which is hereby characterized as a matter of
15 legislative delegation and subject to the guidelines prescribed in K.S.A.
16 75-3711c(c), and amendments thereto. The pooled money investment
17 board is authorized and directed to use any moneys in the operating
18 accounts, investment accounts or other investments of the state of Kansas
19 to provide the funds for each such loan. Each such loan shall bear interest
20 at a rate equal to the net earnings rate for the pooled money investment
21 portfolio at the time of the making of such loan. Such loan shall not be
22 deemed to be an indebtedness or debt of the state of Kansas within the
23 meaning of section 6 of article 11 of the constitution of the state of Kansas.
24 Upon certification to the pooled money investment board by the director of
25 the Kansas water office of the amount of each loan authorized pursuant to
26 this subsection, the pooled money investment board shall transfer each
27 such amount certified by the director of the Kansas water office from the
28 state bank account or accounts to the water marketing fund of the Kansas
29 water office. The principal and interest of each loan authorized pursuant to
30 this subsection shall be repaid in payments payable at least annually for a
31 period of not more than five years.
32 (h) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, the director of
33 accounts and reports shall transfer an amount or amounts specified by the
34 director of the Kansas water office prior to April 1, 2026, from the water
35 marketing fund (709-00-2255-2100) to the state general fund, in
36 accordance with the provisions of the state water plan storage act, K.S.A.
37 82a-1301 et seq., and amendments thereto, and rules and regulations
38 adopted thereunder, for the purposes of making repayments to the state
39 general fund for moneys advanced for annual capital cost payments for
40 water supply storage space in reservoirs.
41 (i) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in addition to the
42 other purposes for which expenditures may be made by the Kansas water
43 office from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or any special

S Sub Sub HB 2007 290
1 revenue fund or funds for the above agency for fiscal year 2026, as

24 being service-related and such service-connected disability is equal to or
25 greater than 30%.

17 Kansas air service development incentive
18 program fund (276-00-2894-2894)..............................................No limit
19 Provided, That all expenditures from the Kansas air service development
20 incentive program fund shall be to support commercial service airports in
21 Kansas: Provided further, That the Kansas department of transportation
22 shall establish requirements for the program, taking into consideration: (1)
23 Recent or imminent regional economic development opportunities,
24 including, but not limited to, new business entering the market area or
25 business growth in the market area; (2) viable air service opportunities,
26 including, but not limited to, airline support service or market data support
27 service; (3) air service routes serving a market area that meets the needs of
28 such economic development opportunities, including, but not limited to,
29 routes establishing a pipeline to areas with workforce talent or serving a
30 customer base or main business function; and (4) local match
31 requirements, including, but not limited to, opportunities to use state or
32 local moneys to leverage federal air service development grant funds: And
33 provided further, That local entities representing commercial service
34 airports may apply for grants from such fund: And provided further, That
35 the Kansas department of transportation shall form a selection committee
36 to evaluate such applications: And provided further, That not more than
37 $1,000,000 shall be awarded for a single commercial service airport: And
38 provided further, That all grant moneys awarded to a local entity shall be
39 deposited in an interest-bearing escrow account: And provided further,
40 That, when awarded a grant, such local entity shall execute a minimum
41 revenue guarantee (MRG) agreement with an airline: And provided further,
42 That such MRG agreement shall describe the thresholds that trigger
43 drawdowns of grant moneys: And provided further, That the Kansas

S Sub Sub HB 2007 299
1 department of transportation shall verify all expenses before authorizing
2 any drawdown of grant moneys from such escrow account.

21 quarterly, on the first day of January, April, July and October, to cities on
22 the state highway system from the state highway fund moneys at the rate
23 of $5,000 per year per lane per mile for the maintenance of streets and
24 highways in cities designated by the secretary as city connecting links:
25 Provided, That all moneys so distributed shall be used solely for the
26 maintenance of city connecting links: Provided further, That such
27 apportionment shall apply only to those city connecting link lanes
28 maintained by the city, and shall not apply to city connecting link lanes
29 maintained by the secretary pursuant to agreement with the city: And
30 provided further, That, as used in this subsection, "lane" means the portion
31 of the roadway for use of moving traffic of a standard width prescribed by
32 the secretary.

11 Sec. 136. (a) On June 30, 2026, notwithstanding the provisions of
12 K.S.A. 74-8768, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, the director
13 of accounts and reports shall transfer the amount of any unencumbered
14 balance in the expanded lottery act revenues fund to the state general fund:
15 Provided, That the transfer of such amount shall be in addition to any other
16 transfer from the expanded lottery act revenues fund to the state general
17 fund as prescribed by law.
18 (b) On June 30, 2026, the director of accounts and reports shall
19 determine and notify the director of the budget if the amount of revenue
20 collected in the expanded lottery act revenues fund for the fiscal year
21 ending June 30, 2026, is insufficient to fund the appropriations and
22 transfers that are authorized from the expanded lottery act revenues fund
23 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in accordance with the provisions
24 of appropriation acts. The director of the budget shall certify to the director
25 of accounts and reports the amount necessary to be transferred from the
26 state general fund to the expanded lottery act revenues fund in order to
27 fund all such appropriations and transfers that are authorized from the
28 expanded lottery act revenues fund for the fiscal year ending June 30,
29 2026. Upon receipt of such certification, the director of accounts and
30 reports shall transfer the amount of moneys from the state general fund to
31 the expanded lottery act revenues fund that is required in accordance with
32 the certification by the director of the budget under this section. At the
33 same time as the director of the budget transmits this certification to the
34 director of accounts and reports, the director of the budget shall transmit a
35 copy of such certification to the director of legislative research.

1 Kansas department for aging and disability services, to convey, without

11 Sec. 138. (a) During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, in
12 addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be made by an
13 executive branch agency from moneys appropriated from the state general
14 fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 as
15 authorized by this or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular
16 session of the legislature, expenditures shall be made by each executive
17 branch agency from such moneys for fiscal year 2026 to require all full-
18 time employees of such executive branch agency to perform such
19 employees' duties in the assigned state office, state facility or field location
20 of such employee: Provided, however, That the provisions of this section
21 shall not apply to employees whose duties require travel.
22 (b) For purposes of this section, "executive branch agency" means all
23 state agencies except the attorney general, insurance department, secretary
24 of state, state treasurer, legislative branch and judicial branch.
25 Sec. 139. During the fiscal years ending June 30, 2025, and June 30,
26 2026, notwithstanding the provisions of any law to the contrary, no state
27 agency named in chapter 88 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas, this or
28 any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature
29 shall expend or transfer any moneys appropriated from the state general
30 fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal years 2025 and
31 2026 as authorized by chapters 88, 110 and 111 of the 2024 Session Laws
32 of Kansas, this or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session
33 of the legislature, that are identified as interest earned on any moneys to
34 the state for aid for coronavirus relief, specifically including interest
35 earnings in any such state agency American rescue plan state relief fund,
36 American rescue plan state relief federal fund or American rescue plan
37 state fiscal relief federal fund except for expenditures or transfers
38 specifically authorized by appropriation acts of the legislature: Provided,
39 That the state treasurer shall identify and certify, in consultation with the
40 director of legislative research, the amount of such interest earnings:
41 Provided further, That, on and after May 1, 2025, as such identified
42 interest earnings are interest earnings on state moneys as provided for in
43 K.S.A. 75-4210a, and amendments thereto, such identified interest

S Sub Sub HB 2007 305
1 earnings shall be credited to the state general fund as provided in K.S.A.
2 75-4210a, and amendments thereto: And provided further, That such
3 interest earnings shall be expended or transferred from the state general
4 fund as specified by appropriation acts of the legislature.
5 Sec. 140. For fiscal year 2026, on June 1, 2026, the director of
6 personnel services of the department of administration, in consultation
7 with the director of the budget and the director of legislative research, shall
8 identify positions and the funding associated with such positions in each
9 state agency that have been vacant for a part of or the entire fiscal year
10 2026 and that are paid from appropriations from the state general fund:
11 Provided, That the director of the budget shall certify such amount in each
12 state general fund account that was not expended for positions during
13 fiscal year 2026 for the purposes of this section to the director of accounts
14 and reports: Provided further, That on June 30, 2026, the amount of
15 funding associated with such vacant positions in each state agency that are
16 paid from appropriations from the state general fund is hereby lapsed: And
17 provided further, That at the same time that such certification is made, the
18 director of the budget shall deliver a copy of such certification to the
19 director of legislative research.

6 used for the purpose of providing the Kansas department for children and
7 families funding for fiscal year 2025 for the summer ebt program:
8 Provided, however, That the secretary for children and families shall
9 certify to the members of the state finance council that the secretary has
10 requested a waiver from the United States department of agriculture to
11 exclude candy and soft drinks from the definition of eligible foods under 7
12 C.F.R. § 271.2: And provided further, That, as used in this proviso: (1)
13 "Candy" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 79-3602, and amendments
14 thereto; and (2) "soft drinks" means the same as defined in K.S.A. 79-
15 3602, and amendments thereto: And provided further, That upon receipt of
16 such certification from the secretary, the state finance council, acting on
17 this matter, which is hereby characterized as a matter of legislative
18 delegation and subject to the guidelines prescribed in K.S.A. 75-3711c(c),
19 and amendments thereto, is hereby authorized to approve the expenditure
20 of moneys from the summer ebt program account to the Kansas
21 department for children and families for the summer ebt program as
22 administered by such department: Provided, however, That except that
23 such expenditure shall be approved by the governor and the majority of the
24 legislative members of the state finance council and that such approval
25 may also be given while the legislature is in session.

5 (e) Upon recommendation of the director of the budget, the state
6 finance council, acting on this matter, which is hereby characterized as a
7 matter of legislative delegation and subject to the guidelines prescribed in
8 K.S.A. 75-3711c(c), and amendments thereto, is hereby authorized to
9 approve: (1) Increases in expenditure limitations on special revenue funds
10 and accounts and increase the transfers between special revenue funds as
11 necessary to pay the salary increases under this section for the fiscal year
12 ending June 30, 2026; and (2) the expenditure of any remaining moneys in
13 any account appropriated in subsections (a) through (d) to address salary
14 inequities in any state agency as identified by the director of the budget in
15 consultation with the director of personnel services. The director of
16 accounts and reports is hereby authorized and directed to increase
17 expenditure limitations on such special revenue funds and accounts and
18 increase the transfers between special revenue funds in accordance with
19 such approval for the purpose of paying from such funds or accounts the
20 proportionate share of the cost to such funds or accounts, including
21 associated employer contributions, of the salary increases and other
22 amounts specified for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.
23 (f) (1) Except as provided in subsection (f)(3), effective with the first
24 payroll period chargeable to the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all
25 executive branch state agencies shall receive a sum equivalent to the total
26 of 2.5%, rounded to the nearest penny, of the salaries and fringe benefit
27 costs excluding health insurance of all benefits eligible unclassified
28 employees in such agency, to be distributed as a merit pool.
29 (2) Except as provided in subsection (f)(3), effective with the first
30 payroll period chargeable to the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, an
31 executive branch benefits-eligible employee shall be eligible for a salary
32 increase of one step for employees in the classified service, including
33 associated employer contributions, and each pay grade of the classified
34 pay matrix shall be extended upward by one step.
35 (3) Based on the department of administration's 2024 market survey
36 summary, effective with the first payroll period chargeable to the fiscal
37 year ending June 30, 2026, if an executive branch benefits-eligible
38 employee's class/job title is:
39 (A) Under market pay by 10% or greater, such employee's salary
40 shall be increased by the percentage that equals the difference between
41 such under market pay percentage and 10% under market or by 2.5%,
42 whichever is greater; and
43 (B) if an employee's class/job title is under market pay by less than

S Sub Sub HB 2007 309
1 10% and not greater than 10% over market pay, such employee's salary
2 shall be increased by 2.5%.
3 (4) Effective with the first payroll period chargeable to the fiscal year
4 ending June 30, 2026, all legislative branch state agencies shall receive a
5 sum equivalent to the total of 2.5%, rounded to the nearest penny, of the
6 salaries and fringe benefit costs excluding health insurance of all benefits-
7 eligible unclassified employees in such agency, to be distributed as a merit
8 pool.
9 (5) Effective with the first payroll period chargeable to the fiscal year
10 ending June 30, 2026, the judicial branch shall receive a sum equivalent to
11 the total of 2.5%, rounded to the nearest penny, of the salaries and fringe
12 benefit costs excluding health insurance of all benefits-eligible non-judge
13 judicial branch employees in such agency, to be distributed as a merit pool.
14 (6) Effective with the first payroll period chargeable to the fiscal year
15 ending June 30, 2026, the state board of regents and the universities shall
16 receive a sum equivalent to the total of 2.5%, rounded to the nearest penny,
17 of the salaries and fringe benefit costs excluding health insurance of all
18 benefits-eligible employees in such agency, to be distributed as a merit
19 pool.
20 (g) (1) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 46-137a and 46-
21 137b, and amendments thereto, or any other statute, the provisions of
22 subsection (f) shall not apply to the compensation or bi-weekly allowance
23 paid to each member of the legislature.
24 (2) The provisions of subsection (f) shall not apply to state officers
25 elected on a statewide basis.
26 (3) The provisions of subsection (f) shall not apply to justices of the
27 supreme court, judges of the court of appeals, district court judges and
28 district magistrate judges.
29 (4) The provisions of subsection (f) shall not apply to:
30 (A) Teachers and licensed personnel at the Kansas state school for the
31 deaf or the Kansas state school for the blind.
32 (B) Any other employees on a formal, written career progression plan
33 implemented by executive directive.
34 (h) After implementation of subsections (f) and (g), the governor is
35 hereby authorized and directed to modify the pay plan for fiscal year 2026
36 in accordance with this section and to adopt such pay plan so modified.

19 Sec. 148. (a) On July 1, 2025, of each amount appropriated for a
20 state agency for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, by chapter 88, 110 or
21 111 of the 2024 Session Laws of Kansas, this act or other appropriation act
22 of the 2025 regular session of the legislature from the state general fund,
23 that is identified as operating expenditures, including salaries and wages,
24 contractual services, commodities and capital outlay, the sum equal to 3%
25 of the aggregate amount of such operating expenditures is hereby lapsed.
26 (b) On July 1, 2025, of each amount reappropriated for a state agency
27 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, by chapter 88, 110 or 111 of the
28 2024 Session Laws of Kansas, this act or other appropriation act of the
29 2025 regular session of the legislature from the state general fund, that is
30 identified as operating expenditures, including salaries and wages,
31 contractual services, commodities and capital outlay, the sum equal to 3%
32 of the aggregate amount of such operating expenditures is hereby lapsed.
33 (c) This section shall not apply to the following categories of
34 appropriations or reappropriations for fiscal year 2026: Aid to locals,
35 capital improvements, debt service and other assistance.
36 (d) The director of the budget, in consultation with the director of
37 legislative research, shall certify the aggregate amount of the lapses for
38 each state agency subject to the provisions of subsections (a) and (b). The
39 head of each state agency shall determine the amounts and accounts from
40 which to lapse in an amount equal to the aggregate 3% lapse and provide
41 such determination to the director of the budget. The director of the budget
42 shall certify the amount of the lapse in each state general fund account for
43 the purposes of this section to the director of accounts and reports. At the

S Sub Sub HB 2007 312
1 same time that any certification is made, the director of the budget shall
2 deliver a copy of such certification to the director of legislative research.

3 (f) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
4 made by Kansas state university from moneys appropriated from the state
5 general fund or any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026, as
6 authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of
7 the legislature, expenditures may be made by Kansas state university from
8 such moneys for fiscal year 2026 to provide for the issuance of bonds by
9 the Kansas development finance authority in accordance with K.S.A. 74-
10 8905, and amendments thereto, for a capital improvement project to
11 complete the construction, renovation, development and equipment of the
12 animal science arena, agronomy research and innovation center, global
13 center for grain and food innovation, Call hall and Weber hall: Provided,
14 That such capital improvement project is hereby approved for Kansas state
15 university for the purposes of K.S.A. 74-8905(b), and amendments thereto,
16 and the authorization of the issuance of bonds by the Kansas development
17 finance authority in accordance with such statute: Provided further, That
18 Kansas state university may make expenditures from the moneys received
19 from the issuance of any such bonds for such capital improvement project:
20 Provided, however, That expenditures from the moneys received from the
21 issuance of any such bonds for such capital improvement project shall not
22 exceed $23,500,000 plus all amounts required for costs of bond issuance,
23 costs of interest on the bonds issued for such capital improvement project
24 during the construction and renovation of such project and, for a period of
25 not more than one year following completion of such project, credit
26 enhancement costs and any required reserves for the payment of principal
27 and interest on the bonds: And provided further, That all moneys received
28 from the issuance of any such bonds shall be deposited and accounted for
29 as prescribed by applicable bond covenants: And provided further, That
30 debt service for any such bonds for such capital improvement project shall
31 be financed by appropriations from any appropriate special revenue fund
32 or funds: And provided further, That any such bonds and interest thereon
33 shall be an obligation only of the Kansas development finance authority,
34 shall not constitute a debt of the state of Kansas within the meaning of
35 section 6 or 7 of article 11 of the constitution of the state of Kansas and
36 shall not pledge the full faith and credit or the taxing power of the state of
37 Kansas: And provided further, That Kansas state university shall make
38 provisions for the maintenance of the animal science arena, agronomy
39 research and innovation center, global center for grain and food
40 innovation, Call hall and Weber hall.

40 bonds for such capital improvement project shall not exceed $100,000,000
41 plus all amounts required for costs of bond issuance, costs of interest on
42 the bonds issued for such capital improvement project during the
43 construction of such project and, for a period of not more than one year

S Sub Sub HB 2007 333
1 following completion of such project, credit enhancement costs and any
2 required reserves for the payment of principal and interest on the bonds:
3 And provided further, That all moneys received from the issuance of any
4 such bonds shall be deposited and accounted for as prescribed by
5 applicable bond covenants: And provided further, That debt service for any
6 such bonds for such capital improvement project shall be financed by
7 appropriations from any appropriate special revenue fund or funds: And
8 provided further, That any such bonds and interest thereon shall be an
9 obligation only of the Kansas development finance authority, shall not
10 constitute a debt of the state of Kansas within the meaning of section 6 or
11 7 of article 11 of the constitution of the state of Kansas and shall not
12 pledge the full faith and credit or the taxing power of the state of Kansas:
13 And provided further, That the university of Kansas shall make provisions
14 for the maintenance of such capital improvement project and related
15 equipment and infrastructure for student housing.

21 made by the above agency from the moneys appropriated from the state
22 general fund or from any special revenue fund or funds for fiscal year
23 2026, as authorized by this or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular
24 session of the legislature, expenditures may be made by the above agency
25 from moneys appropriated from the state general fund or from any special
26 revenue fund or funds for fiscal year 2026 to provide for the issuance of up
27 to 30-year bonds by the Kansas development finance authority in
28 accordance with K.S.A. 74-8905, and amendments thereto, for a capital
29 improvement project to design, construct and equip a KBI headquarters,
30 including the purchase of land for such KBI headquarters: Provided, That
31 such capital improvement project is hereby approved for the above agency
32 for the purposes of K.S.A. 74-8905(b), and amendments thereto, and the
33 authorization of the issuance of bonds by the Kansas development finance
34 authority in accordance with such statute: Provided further, That the above
35 agency may make expenditures from the moneys received from the
36 issuance of any such bonds for such capital improvement project:
37 Provided, however, That expenditures from the moneys received from the
38 issuance of any such bonds for such capital improvement project shall not
39 exceed $100,000,000 plus all amounts required for costs of bond issuance,
40 costs of interest on the bonds issued for such capital improvement project
41 during the construction and renovation of such project and, for a period of
42 not more than one year following completion of such project, credit
43 enhancement costs and any required reserves for the payment of principal

S Sub Sub HB 2007 342
1 and interest on the bonds: And provided further, That all moneys received
2 from the issuance of any such bonds shall be deposited and accounted for
3 as prescribed by applicable bond covenants: And provided further, That
4 debt service for any such bonds for such capital improvement project shall
5 be financed by appropriations from the state general fund or any
6 appropriate special revenue fund or funds: And provided further, That any
7 such bonds and interest thereon shall be an obligation only of the Kansas
8 development finance authority, shall not constitute a debt of the state of
9 Kansas within the meaning of section 6 or 7 of article 11 of the
10 constitution of the state of Kansas and shall not pledge the full faith and
11 credit or the taxing power of the state of Kansas: And provided further,
12 That the above agency shall make provisions for the maintenance of the
13 KBI headquarters: Provided, however, That prior to the issuance of such
14 bonds, the above agency shall advise and consult with the joint committee
15 on state building construction on such KBI headquarters: And provided
16 however, That the issuance of such bonds shall be subject to approval by
17 the state finance council acting on this matter, which is hereby
18 characterized as a matter of legislative delegation and subject to the
19 guidelines prescribed in K.S.A. 75-3711c(c), and amendments thereto,
20 except that such approval also may be given when the legislature is in
21 session.

24 an amount on March 1, 2024 2025, to the director of accounts and reports

18 Sec. 182. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 12-1775a is hereby amended to read as
19 follows: 12-1775a. (a) Prior to December 31, 1996, the governing body of
20 each city that, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1771, and amendments thereto, has
21 established a redevelopment district prior to July 1, 1996, shall certify to
22 the director of accounts and reports the amount equal to the amount of
23 revenue realized from ad valorem taxes imposed pursuant to K.S.A. 72-
24 5142, and amendments thereto, within such redevelopment district. Except
25 as provided further, to February 1, 1997, and annually on that date
26 thereafter, the governing body of each such city shall certify to the director
27 of accounts and reports an amount equal to the amount by which revenues
28 realized from such ad valorem taxes imposed in such redevelopment
29 district are estimated to be reduced for the ensuing calendar year due to
30 legislative changes in the statewide school finance formula. Prior to March
31 1 of each year, the director of accounts and reports shall certify to the state
32 treasurer each amount certified by the governing bodies of cities under this
33 section for the ensuing calendar year and shall transfer from the state
34 general fund to the city tax increment financing revenue replacement fund
35 the aggregate of all amounts so certified. Prior to April 15 of each year, the
36 state treasurer shall pay from the city tax increment financing revenue
37 replacement fund to each city certifying an amount to the director of
38 accounts and reports under this section for the ensuing calendar year the
39 amount so certified. During fiscal years 2024, 2025 and, 2026 and 2027,
40 no moneys shall be transferred from the state general fund to the city tax
41 increment financing revenue replacement fund pursuant to this subsection.
42 (b) There is hereby created the tax increment financing revenue
43 replacement fund, which shall be administered by the state treasurer. All

S Sub Sub HB 2007 352
1 expenditures from the tax increment financing revenue replacement fund
2 shall be made in accordance with appropriations acts upon warrants of the
3 director of accounts and reports issued pursuant to vouchers approved by
4 the state treasurer or a person or persons designated by the state treasurer.
5 Sec. 183. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 12-5256 is hereby amended to read as
6 follows: 12-5256. (a) All expenditures from the state housing trust fund
7 made for the purposes of K.S.A. 12-5253 through 12-5255, and
8 amendments thereto, shall be made in accordance with appropriation acts
9 upon warrants of the director of accounts and reports issued pursuant to
10 vouchers approved by the president of the Kansas housing resources
11 corporation.
12 (b) (1) On July 1, 2023, July 1, 2024, and July 1, 2025 July 1, 2026,
13 the director of accounts and reports shall transfer $2,000,000 from the state
14 economic development initiatives fund to the state housing trust fund
15 established by K.S.A. 74-8959, and amendments thereto.
16 (2) Notwithstanding the provisions of K.S.A. 74-8959, and
17 amendments thereto, to the contrary, during fiscal year 2024, fiscal year
18 2025 and, fiscal year 2026 and fiscal year 2027, moneys in the state
19 housing trust fund shall be used solely for the purpose of loans or grants to
20 cities or counties for infrastructure or housing development in rural areas.
21 During such fiscal years, on or before January 13, 2025, January 12, 2026,
22 and January 11, 2027, and January 10, 2028, the president of the Kansas
23 housing resources corporation shall submit a report concerning the
24 activities of the state housing trust fund to the house of representatives
25 committee on appropriations and the senate committee on ways and
26 means.
27 Sec. 184. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 65-180 is hereby amended to read as
28 follows: 65-180. The secretary of health and environment shall:
29 (a) Institute and carry on an intensive educational program among
30 physicians, hospitals, public health nurses and the public concerning
31 congenital hypothyroidism, galactosemia, phenylketonuria and other
32 genetic diseases detectable with the same specimen. This educational
33 program shall include information about the nature of such conditions and
34 examinations for the detection thereof in early infancy in order that
35 measures may be taken to prevent intellectual disability or morbidity
36 resulting from such conditions.
37 (b) Provide recognized screening tests for phenylketonuria,
38 galactosemia, hypothyroidism and such other diseases as may be
39 appropriately detected with the same specimen. The initial laboratory
40 screening tests for these diseases shall be performed by the department of
41 health and environment or its designee for all infants born in the state.
42 Such services shall be performed without charge.
43 (c) Provide a follow-up program by providing test results and other

S Sub Sub HB 2007 353
1 information to identified physicians; locate infants with abnormal newborn
2 screening test results; with parental consent, monitor infants to assure
3 appropriate testing to either confirm or not confirm the disease suggested
4 by the screening test results; with parental consent, monitor therapy and
5 treatment for infants with confirmed diagnosis of congenital
6 hypothyroidism, galactosemia, phenylketonuria or other genetic diseases
7 being screened under this statute; and establish ongoing education and
8 support activities for individuals with confirmed diagnosis of congenital
9 hypothyroidism, galactosemia, phenylketonuria and other genetic diseases
10 being screened under this statute and for the families of such individuals.
11 (d) Maintain a registry of cases including information of importance
12 for the purpose of follow-up services to prevent intellectual disability or
13 morbidity.
14 (e) Provide, within the limits of appropriations available therefor, the
15 necessary treatment product for diagnosed cases for as long as medically
16 indicated, when the product is not available through other state agencies.
17 In addition to diagnosed cases under this section, diagnosed cases of maple
18 syrup urine disease shall be included as a diagnosed case under this
19 subsection. Where the applicable income of the person or persons who
20 have legal responsibility for the diagnosed individual meets medicaid
21 eligibility, such individuals' needs shall be covered under the medicaid
22 state plan. Where the applicable income of the person or persons who have
23 legal responsibility for the diagnosed individual is not medicaid eligible,
24 but is below 300% of the federal poverty level established under the most
25 recent poverty guidelines issued by the United States department of health
26 and human services, the department of health and environment shall
27 provide reimbursement of between 50% to 100% of the product cost in
28 accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the secretary of health
29 and environment. Where the applicable income of the person or persons
30 who have legal responsibility for the diagnosed individual exceeds 300%
31 of the federal poverty level established under the most recent poverty
32 guidelines issued by the United States department of health and human
33 services, the department of health and environment shall provide
34 reimbursement of an amount not to exceed 50% of the product cost in
35 accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the secretary of health
36 and environment.
37 (f) Provide state assistance to an applicant pursuant to subsection (e)
38 only after it has been shown that the applicant has exhausted all benefits
39 from private third-party payers, medicare, medicaid and other government
40 assistance programs and after consideration of the applicant's income and
41 assets. The secretary of health and environment shall adopt rules and
42 regulations establishing standards for determining eligibility for state
43 assistance under this section.

S Sub Sub HB 2007 354
1 (g) (1) Except for treatment products provided under subsection (e), if
2 the medically necessary food treatment product for diagnosed cases must
3 be purchased, the purchaser shall be reimbursed by the department of
4 health and environment for costs incurred up to $1,500 per year per
5 diagnosed child age 18 or younger at 100% of the product cost upon
6 submission of a receipt of purchase identifying the company from which
7 the product was purchased. For a purchaser to be eligible for
8 reimbursement under this subsection, the applicable income of the person
9 or persons who have legal responsibility for the diagnosed child shall not
10 exceed 300% of the poverty level established under the most recent
11 poverty guidelines issued by the federal department of health and human
12 services.
13 (2) As an option to reimbursement authorized under subsection (g)
14 (1), the department of health and environment may purchase food
15 treatment products for distribution to diagnosed children in an amount not
16 to exceed $1,500 per year per diagnosed child age 18 or younger. For a
17 diagnosed child to be eligible for the distribution of food treatment
18 products under this subsection, the applicable income of the person or
19 persons who have legal responsibility for the diagnosed child shall not
20 exceed 300% of the poverty level established under the most recent
21 poverty guidelines issued by the federal department of health and human
22 services.
23 (3) In addition to diagnosed cases under this section, diagnosed cases
24 of maple syrup urine disease shall be included as a diagnosed case under
25 this subsection.
26 (h) The department of health and environment shall continue to
27 receive orders for both necessary treatment products and necessary food
28 treatment products, purchase such products, and shall deliver the products
29 to an address prescribed by the diagnosed individual. The department of
30 health and environment shall bill the person or persons who have legal
31 responsibility for the diagnosed patient for a pro-rata share of the total
32 costs, in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to this
33 section.
34 (i) The secretary of health and environment shall adopt rules and
35 regulations as needed to require, to the extent of available funding,
36 newborn screening tests to screen for treatable disorders listed in the core
37 uniform panel of newborn screening conditions recommended in the 2005
38 report by the American college of medical genetics entitled "Newborn
39 Screening: Toward a Uniform Screening Panel and System" or another
40 report determined by the department of health and environment to provide
41 more appropriate newborn screening guidelines to protect the health and
42 welfare of newborns for treatable disorders.
43 (j) In performing the duties under subsection (i), the secretary of

S Sub Sub HB 2007 355
1 health and environment shall appoint an advisory council to advise the
2 department of health and environment on implementation of subsection (i).
3 (k) The department of health and environment shall periodically
4 review the newborn screening program to determine the efficacy and cost
5 effectiveness of the program and determine whether adjustments to the
6 program are necessary to protect the health and welfare of newborns and
7 to maximize the number of newborn screenings that may be conducted
8 with the funding available for the screening program.
9 (l) There is hereby established in the state treasury the Kansas
10 newborn screening fund that shall be administered by the secretary of
11 health and environment. All expenditures from the fund shall be for the
12 newborn screening program. All expenditures from the fund shall be made
13 in accordance with appropriation acts upon warrants of the director of

21 environment or the secretary's designee to the Kansas newborn screening
22 fund. Such amount shall not exceed $5,000,000 in fiscal years 2024, 2025
23 and, 2026 and 2027.

3 Sec. 188. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 75-2263 is hereby amended to read as
4 follows: 75-2263. (a) (1) The state treasurer shall certify to the board of
5 trustees a portion of state moneys available for investment by the pooled
6 money investment board that is equivalent to the aggregate net amount
7 received for unclaimed property. The state treasurer may transfer the
8 amount certified to the board of trustees. All such moneys shall be
9 considered moneys in the state treasury for purposes of K.S.A. 75-6704,
10 and amendments thereto.
11 (2) Subject to the provisions of subsection (h), the board of trustees is
12 responsible for the management and investment of that portion of state
13 moneys available for investment by the pooled money investment board
14 that is certified by the state treasurer to the board of trustees as being
15 equivalent to the aggregate net amount received for unclaimed property
16 and shall discharge the board's duties with respect to such moneys solely
17 in the interests of the state general fund and shall invest and reinvest such
18 moneys and acquire, retain, manage, including the exercise of any voting
19 rights and disposal of investments of such moneys within the limitations
20 and according to the powers, duties and purposes as prescribed by this
21 section.
22 (3) During the fiscal years ending June 30, 2025, June 30, 2026, and
23 June 30, 2027, following the receipt of the certification from the director
24 of the budget pursuant to K.S.A. 75-6707, and amendments thereto, the
25 state treasurer shall certify to the board of trustees the amount equal to
26 50% of the balance in the budget stabilization fund. The state treasurer
27 shall transfer the amount certified to the board of trustees. All such
28 moneys shall be considered moneys in the state treasury for purposes of
29 K.S.A. 75-6704, and amendments thereto. During the fiscal years ending
30 June 30, 2025, June 30, 2026, and June 30, 2027, the board of trustees is
31 responsible for the management and investment of that portion of the
32 budget stabilization fund that is certified by the state treasurer to the
33 board of trustees and shall discharge the board's duties with respect to
34 such moneys solely in the interests of the state general fund and shall
35 invest and reinvest such moneys and acquire, retain, manage, including
36 the exercise of any voting rights and disposal of investments of such
37 moneys within the limitations and according to the powers, duties and
38 purposes as prescribed by this section.
39 (b) Moneys specified in subsection (a) shall be invested and
40 reinvested to achieve the investment objective, which is preservation of
41 such moneys and accordingly providing that the moneys are as productive
42 as possible, subject to the standards set forth in this section. No such
43 moneys shall be invested or reinvested if the sole or primary investment

S Sub Sub HB 2007 361
1 objective is for economic development or social purposes or objectives.
2 (c) In investing and reinvesting moneys specified in subsection (a)
3 and in acquiring, retaining, managing and disposing of investments of the
4 moneys, the board of trustees shall exercise the judgment, care, skill,
5 prudence and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that
6 persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence acting in a like capacity
7 and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise of
8 like character and with like aims by diversifying the investments of the
9 moneys so as to minimize the risk of large losses, unless under the
10 circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so, and not in regard to
11 speculation but in regard to the permanent disposition of similar moneys,
12 considering the probable income as well as the probable safety of their
13 capital.
14 (d) In the discharge of such management and investment
15 responsibilities the board of trustees may:
16 (1) Contract for the services of one or more professional investment
17 advisors or other consultants in the management and investment of such
18 moneys and otherwise in the performance of the duties of the board of
19 trustees under this section; and
20 (2) arrange for the custody of such moneys as the board of trustees
21 considers advisable with one or more member banks or trust companies of
22 the federal reserve system or with one or more banks in the state of
23 Kansas, or both, to be held in safekeeping by the banks or trust companies
24 for the collection of the principal and interest or other income or of the
25 proceeds of sale.
26 (e) The board of trustees shall require that each person contracted
27 with under subsection (d) to provide services shall obtain commercial
28 insurance that provides for errors and omissions coverage for such person
29 in an amount to be specified by the board of trustees. The amount of such
30 coverage specified by the board of trustees shall be at least the greater of
31 $500,000 or 1% of the funds entrusted to such person up to a maximum of
32 $10,000,000. The board of trustees shall require a person contracted with
33 under subsection (d) to provide services to give a fidelity bond in a penal
34 sum as may be fixed by law or, if not so fixed, as may be fixed by the
35 board of trustees, with corporate surety authorized to do business in this
36 state. Such persons contracted with the board of trustees pursuant to
37 subsection (d) and any persons contracted with such persons to perform
38 the functions specified in subsection (b) shall be deemed to be fiduciary
39 agents of the board of trustees in the performance of contractual
40 obligations.
41 (f) (1) Subject to the objective set forth in subsection (b) and the
42 standards set forth in subsection (c), the board of trustees shall formulate
43 and adopt policies and objectives for the investment and reinvestment of

S Sub Sub HB 2007 362
1 such moneys and the acquisition, retention, management and disposition of
2 investments of the moneys. Such policies and objectives shall be in writing
3 and shall include:
4 (A) Specific asset allocation standards and objectives;
5 (B) establishment of criteria for evaluating the risk versus the
6 potential return on a particular investment; and
7 (C) a requirement that all investment advisors, and any managers or
8 others with similar duties and responsibilities as investment advisors, shall
9 immediately report all instances of default on investments to the board of
10 trustees and provide such board of trustees with recommendations and
11 options, including, but not limited to, curing the default or withdrawal
12 from the investment.
13 (2) The board of trustees shall review such policies and objectives,
14 make changes considered necessary or desirable and readopt such policies
15 and objectives on an annual basis.
16 (g) All interest or other income of the investments of the moneys
17 invested under this section, after payment of any management fees, shall
18 be deposited in the state treasury to the credit of the state general fund.
19 (h) The state treasurer shall maintain the discretionary authority to
20 liquidate some or a portion of such moneys transferred to the board of
21 trustees pursuant to subsection (a)(1) and (2) for:
22 (1) Investment by the pooled money investment board; or
23 (2) necessary payments to owners as defined in K.S.A. 58-3934(m),
24 and amendments thereto.
25 (i) As used in this section:
26 (1) "Board of trustees" means the board of trustees of the Kansas
27 public employees retirement system established by K.S.A. 74-4905, and
28 amendments thereto.
29 (2) "Fiduciary" means a person who, with respect to the moneys
30 invested under this section:
31 (A) Exercises any discretionary authority with respect to
32 administration of the moneys;
33 (B) exercises any authority to invest or manage such moneys or has
34 any authority or responsibility to do so;
35 (C) provides investment advice for a fee or other direct or indirect
36 compensation with respect to such moneys or has any authority or
37 responsibility to do so;
38 (D) provides actuarial, accounting, auditing, consulting, legal or other
39 professional services for a fee or other direct or indirect compensation with
40 respect to such moneys or has any authority or responsibility to do so; or
41 (E) is a member of the board of trustees or of the staff of the board of
42 trustees.
43 (3) "Pooled money investment board" means the pooled money

S Sub Sub HB 2007 363
1 investment board established by K.S.A. 75-4221a, and amendments
2 thereto.
3 Sec. 189. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 75-5748 is hereby amended to read as
4 follows: 75-5748.(a) There is hereby created in the state treasury the
5 Kansas sheltered workshop transition fund. The secretary of labor shall
6 administer the fund. All expenditures from the fund shall be for the
7 purpose of facilitating transitions by Kansas sheltered workshop
8 employers away from employing individuals with disabilities under a
9 certificate issued by the United States secretary of labor under 29 U.S.C. §
10 214(c) and toward paying all such employees at least the minimum wage.
11 Such purpose shall be achieved by providing matching grants from fund
12 moneys to Kansas sheltered workshop employers that commit to paying at
13 least the minimum wage to all employees. A grant shall be matched on a
14 $1-to-$1 basis by the Kansas sheltered workshop employer from nonstate
15 sources.
16 (b) Applications for matching grants shall be made by Kansas
17 sheltered workshop employers to the secretary in the form and manner
18 required by the secretary. In determining whether applicants should be
19 approved and receive a grant, the secretary shall seek the assistance of the
20 secretary for children and families, the secretary for aging and disability
21 services or any other appropriate state agency. The secretary for children
22 and families, secretary for aging and disability services or other state
23 agency shall provide such assistance to the secretary as requested by the
24 secretary. The applicant shall provide a transition plan to the secretary
25 demonstrating how the applicant will use the grant and other funding to
26 transition away from use of a certificate issued by the United States
27 secretary of labor under 29 U.S.C. § 214(c). The Kansas sheltered
28 workshop shall commit to completing the plan to receive a grant. If the
29 secretary approves the transition plan, finds that the Kansas sheltered
30 workshop has sufficient nonstate funding to match the grant with nonstate
31 funds on a $1-to-$1 basis and approves the application, the secretary shall
32 award the Kansas sheltered workshop a matching grant in the amount
33 determined by the secretary. The secretary may award subsequent
34 additional grants to the same Kansas sheltered workshop employer upon
35 satisfactory progress shown by such workshop employer pursuant to the
36 workshop employer's transition plan.
37 (c) Kansas sheltered workshop employers that receive a matching
38 grant shall provide such information to the secretary as requested,
39 excluding any information prohibited from disclosure under state or
40 federal law, regarding the use of grant funds, use of associated nonstate
41 funds and progress made toward achievement of the transition plan as
42 developed pursuant to subsection (b). Such information shall be utilized by
43 the secretary to analyze and monitor the use of grant funds and compliance

S Sub Sub HB 2007 364
1 with and progress toward completion of the transition plan by workshop
2 employers and to develop best uses of grant funds and transition methods
3 to attain the goal of K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 75-5747 through 75-5749, and
4 amendments thereto.
5 (d) On or before January 31, 2025, and annually on or before January
6 31 thereafter, the secretary shall report to the house of representatives
7 standing committee on commerce, labor and economic development or its
8 successor committee and the senate standing committee on commerce or
9 its successor committee on the amount and uses of grant funding by each
10 Kansas sheltered workshop employer that has received a matching grant
11 and the progress made by each Kansas sheltered workshop employer
12 toward the goal of K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 75-5747 through 75-5749, and
13 amendments thereto.
14 (e) All expenditures from the Kansas sheltered workshop transition
15 fund shall be for the purpose described in subsection (a) and shall be made
16 in accordance with appropriation acts upon warrants of the director of
17 accounts and reports issued pursuant to vouchers approved by the
18 secretary of labor or the secretary's designee.
19 (f) Except as provided further, on July 1, 2024, and each July 1
20 thereafter, or as soon thereafter as moneys may be available, the director of
21 accounts and reports shall transfer $1,000,000 from the state economic
22 development initiatives fund established by K.S.A. 79-4804, and
23 amendments thereto, to the Kansas sheltered workshop transition fund. No
24 moneys shall be transferred from the state economic development
25 initiatives fund to the Kansas sheltered workshop transition fund during
26 the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026.
27 Sec. 190. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 75-6706 is hereby amended to read as
28 follows: 75-6706. (a) On July 1, 2017, The budget stabilization fund is
29 hereby established in the state treasury.
30 (b) (1) Except as provided in subsection (b)(2), on or before the 10th
31 day of each month commencing July 1, 2017, the director of accounts and
32 reports shall transfer from the state general fund to the budget stabilization
33 fund interest earnings based on:
34 (1)(A) The average daily balance of moneys in the budget
35 stabilization fund, for the preceding month; and
36 (2)(B) the net earnings rate of the pooled money investment portfolio
37 for the preceding month.
38 (2) Pursuant to the provisions of K.S.A. 75-6707, and amendments
39 thereto, during the fiscal years ending June 30, 2025, June 30, 2026, and
40 June 30, 2027, all interest or other income of the investments of the budget
41 stabilization fund shall be deposited in the state treasury to the credit of
42 the state general fund.
43 (c) On and after July 1, 2017, No moneys in the budget stabilization

S Sub Sub HB 2007 365
1 fund shall be expended pursuant to this subsection unless the expenditure
2 either has been approved by an appropriation or other act of the legislature
3 or has been approved by the state finance council acting on this matter
4 which is hereby characterized as a matter of legislative delegation and
5 subject to the guidelines prescribed in K.S.A. 75-3711(c), and amendments
6 thereto.
7 (d) (1) The legislative budget committee shall study and review the
8 policy concerning the balance of, transfers to and expenditures from the
9 budget stabilization fund. The legislative budget committee study and
10 review shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
11 (A) Risk-based budget stabilization fund practices utilized in other
12 states.
13 (B) The appropriate number of years to review the state general fund:
14 (i) Revenue variances from projections; and
15 (ii) expenditure variances from budgets.
16 (C) The entity to certify the amount necessary in the budget
17 stabilization fund to maintain the appropriate risk-based balance.
18 (D) Plan to fund the budget stabilization fund.
19 (E) Process and circumstances to reach the appropriate risk-based
20 balance, including the amount of risk that is acceptable.
21 (F) Circumstances under which expenditures may be made from the
22 fund.
23 (2) The legislative budget committee may make recommendations
24 and introduce legislation as it deems necessary to implement such
25 recommendations.
26 (e) On July 1, 2021, the director of accounts and reports shall transfer
27 all moneys in the budget stabilization fund to the state general fund.

42 the state water plan fund to be used to supplement salaries of existing state
43 agency full-time equivalent employees and for funding new full-time

S Sub Sub HB 2007 372
1 equivalent positions created to implement the state water plan. Moneys
2 from such appropriation may be used to supplement existing positions, but
3 such moneys shall not be used to replace state general fund moneys, any
4 fee fund moneys or other funding for positions existing on July 1, 2023.
5 (B) Eligible full-time equivalent positions that moneys may be used
6 for pursuant to this paragraph include engineers, geologists, hydrologists,
7 environmental scientists, attorneys, resource planners, grant specialists and
8 any other similar positions.

10 Kansas water authority for a position or positions to provide shared
11 services to all districts involved in such proposal, the Kansas water
12 authority may recommend that moneys be used to supplement the salary or
13 salaries of such position or positions pursuant to paragraph (1).

15 state and local entities that cooperate with qualified nonprofit entities on
16 projects that provide a direct benefit to water quantity and quality,
17 including water infrastructures that are both natural and constructed, and
18 include matching funds from non-state sources.

20 provide funding pursuant to K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 82a-956 or 82a-957, and
21 amendments thereto, for the improvement of water infrastructure in an
22 unincorporated area related to or serving a national park site or state
23 historic site if the request for funding is made by a nonprofit organization

27 Kansas water office may award moneys in any fiscal year prior to July 1,

29 Kansas water office.

31 programs for stockwatering conservation projects. Such grant programs
32 shall prioritize the use of fees collected pursuant to K.S.A. 82a-954(a)(3),
33 and amendments thereto.

39 Sec. 200. If any fund or account name described by words and the
40 numerical accounting code that follows such fund or account name do not
41 match, it shall be conclusively presumed that the legislature intended that
42 the fund or account name described by words is the correct fund or
43 account name, and such fund or account name described by words shall

S Sub Sub HB 2007 373
1 control over a contradictory or incorrect numerical accounting code.
2 Sec. 201. Severability. If any provision or clause of this act or
3 application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such
4 invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this act that
5 can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this
6 end, the provisions of this act are declared to be severable.
7 Sec. 202. Appeals to exceed expenditure limitations. (a) Upon written
8 application to the governor and approval of the state finance council,
9 expenditures from special revenue funds may exceed the amounts
10 specified in this act.
11 (b) This section shall not apply to the expanded lottery act revenues
12 fund, the state economic development initiatives fund, the children's
13 initiative fund, the state water plan fund or the Kansas endowment for
14 youth fund, or to any account of any such funds.
15 Sec. 203. Savings. (a) Any unencumbered balance as of June 30,
16 2025, in any special revenue fund, or account thereof, of any state agency
17 named in this act that is not otherwise specifically appropriated or limited
18 for fiscal year 2026 by this or any other appropriation act of the 2025
19 regular session of the legislature is hereby appropriated for the fiscal year
20 ending June 30, 2026, for the same use and purpose as the same was
21 heretofore appropriated.
22 (b) This section shall not apply to the expanded lottery act revenues
23 fund, the state economic development initiatives fund, the children's
24 initiatives fund, the state water plan fund, the Kansas endowment for youth
25 fund, the Kansas educational building fund, the state institutions building
26 fund or the correctional institutions building fund, or to any account of any
27 of such funds.
28 Sec. 204. During the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, all moneys
29 that are lawfully credited to and available in any bond special revenue
30 fund and that are not otherwise specifically appropriated or limited by this
31 or other appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature are
32 hereby appropriated for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for the state
33 agency for which the bond special revenue fund was established for the
34 purposes authorized by law for expenditures from such bond special
35 revenue fund. As used in this section, "bond special revenue fund" means
36 any special revenue fund or account thereof established in the state
37 treasury prior to or on or after the effective date of this act for the deposit
38 of the proceeds of bonds issued by the Kansas development finance
39 authority for the payment of debt service for bonds issued by the Kansas
40 development finance authority or for any related purpose in accordance
41 with applicable bond covenants.
42 Sec. 205. Federal grants. (a) During the fiscal year ending June 30,
43 2026, each federal grant or other federal receipt that is received by a state

S Sub Sub HB 2007 374
1 agency named in this act and that is not otherwise appropriated to that state
2 agency for fiscal year 2026 by this or other appropriation act of the 2025
3 regular session of the legislature is hereby appropriated for fiscal year
4 2026 for that state agency for the purpose set forth in such federal grant or
5 receipt, except that no expenditure shall be made from and no obligation
6 shall be incurred against any such federal grant or other federal receipt that
7 has not been previously appropriated or reappropriated or approved for
8 expenditure by the governor until the governor has authorized the state
9 agency to make expenditures therefrom.
10 (b) In addition to the other purposes for which expenditures may be
11 made by any state agency that is named in this act and that is not otherwise
12 authorized by law to apply for and receive federal grants, expenditures
13 may be made by such state agency from moneys appropriated for fiscal
14 year 2026 by this act or any other appropriation act of the 2025 regular
15 session of the legislature to apply for and receive federal grants during
16 fiscal year 2026, which federal grants are hereby authorized to be applied
17 for and received by such state agencies: Provided, That no expenditure
18 shall be made from and no obligation shall be incurred against any such
19 federal grant or other federal receipt that has not been previously
20 appropriated or reappropriated or approved for expenditure by the
21 governor until the governor has authorized the state agency to make
22 expenditures therefrom.
23 Sec. 206. (a) Any correctional institutions building fund appropriation
24 heretofore appropriated to any state agency named in this or other
25 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature and having
26 an unencumbered balance as of June 30, 2025, in excess of $100 is hereby
27 reappropriated for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for the same uses
28 and purposes as originally appropriated, unless specific provision is made
29 for lapsing such appropriation.
30 (b) This subsection shall not apply to the unencumbered balance in
31 any account of the correctional institutions building fund that was
32 encumbered for any fiscal year commencing prior to July 1, 2024.
33 Sec. 207. (a) Any Kansas educational building fund appropriation
34 heretofore appropriated to any institution named in this or other
35 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature and having
36 an unencumbered balance as of June 30, 2025, in excess of $100 is hereby
37 reappropriated for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for the same use
38 and purpose as originally appropriated, unless specific provision is made
39 for lapsing such appropriation.
40 (b) This subsection shall not apply to the unencumbered balance in
41 any account of the Kansas educational building fund that was encumbered
42 for any fiscal year commencing prior to July 1, 2024.
43 Sec. 208. (a) Any state institutions building fund appropriation

S Sub Sub HB 2007 375
1 heretofore appropriated to any state agency named in this or other
2 appropriation act of the 2025 regular session of the legislature and having
3 an unencumbered balance as of June 30, 2025, in excess of $100 is hereby
4 reappropriated for the fiscal year ending June 30, 2026, for the same use
5 and purpose as originally appropriated, unless specific provision is made
6 for lapsing such appropriation.
7 (b) This subsection shall not apply to the unencumbered balance in
8 any account of the state institutions building fund that was encumbered for
9 any fiscal year commencing prior to July 1, 2024.
10 Sec. 209. Any transfers of moneys during the fiscal year ending June
11 30, 2026, from any special revenue fund of any state agency named in this
12 act to the audit services fund of the division of post audit under K.S.A. 46-
13 1121, and amendments thereto, shall be in addition to any expenditure
14 limitation imposed on any such fund for the fiscal year ending June 30,
15 2026.
16 Sec. 210. K.S.A. 2024 Supp. 2-223, 12-1775a, 12-5256, 65-180, 74-
17 50,107, 74-8711, 74-99b34, 75-2263, 75-5748, 75-6706, 75-6707, 76-775,
18 76-7,107, 76-7,155, 79-2989, 79-3425i, 79-34,171, 79-4804 and 82a-955
19 are hereby repealed.
20 Sec. 211. This act shall take effect and be in force from and after its
21 publication in the Kansas register.
